The resulting stress image shows a decrease of Coulomb stress along a wide NNE-SSW trending belt including the fault plane, and two pairs of narrow lobes of increased ΔCFS at the fault plane tips. For comparison, epicenters following the mainshock during the next 38 hours are shown in Fig. 9. The vast majority of these events occurred in the positive Coulomb stress areas, indicating that these are aftershocks of the ML 5.3 earthquake. These include both the events to the WSW illuminating the oblique rift zone segment, and the first events of the earthquake swarm in the NE dyke segment #1. Interestingly, no aftershocks are observed in the southern positive ΔCFS lobes.


4.3
Magmatic dykes in extensional settings
Lateral migration of a magma-filled dyke, sometimes up to tens of kilometers, frequently precede volcanic eruptions (e.g., Ágústsdóttir et al., 2016; Woods et al., 2019). Some of these dyke intrusions freeze at depth (e.g. White et al., 2011) while others breach the surface, resulting in a fissure eruption (e.g., Hamling et al., 2009; Wright et al., 2012; Sigmundsson et al., 2015). Pre-existing stresses and material properties of the rift fabric, in this case, strongly influence the extent of the accompanying seismicity (Rubin and Gillard, 1998; Rivalta et al., 2015). Many examples exist on seismicity accompanying a dyke propagation (Battaglia et al., 2005; Morita et al., 2006; Keir et al., 2009; Ágústsdóttir et al., 2016). However, unlike in these examples, the magma feeding the propagating dyke preceding the 2021 Fagradalsfjall eruption originated not from a deflating crustal magma chamber, but was instead mantle-sourced (Sigmundsson et al., 2021). No known magma chambers nor acidic rocks are found on the Reykjanes Peninsula (Sæmundsson et al., 2020). It is unclear if the episodic seismic activity on the Reykjanes Peninsula is of tectonic origin only, or if some of the earthquake swarms are of magmatic origin without any eruption (Björnsson et al., 2020 and references therein).
We find that the earthquake swarm in the NE dyke segment #1 following the ML 5.3 mainshock on 24 February 2021 originates in the positive Coulomb stress change area (Fig. 9). Therefore, we infer that the earthquake swarm, later confirmed as a dyke propagation, was triggered by the ML 5.3 mainshock. Large earthquakes in Iceland have promoted failure in increased Coulomb stress areas, such as the aftershocks of the 2000 SISZ event (Árnadóttir et al., 2003).
Another interesting observation of the 2021 Fagradalsfjall dyke is the concentration of seismicity, which is mainly located at 2–6 km depth (Fig. 2). Very little seismicity is observed above 2 km depth, where ambient differential stresses were likely not high enough to produce earthquakes. Ágústsdóttir et al. (2016) made a similar observation for the 2014 Bárðarbunga-Holuhraun dyke in NE Iceland. Similarly, Woods et al. (2019) applied Coulomb Stress modeling for the 2014 Bárðarbunga-Holuhraun dyke and showed that the dyke seismicity was concentrated at the base of the dyke at 6 km depth, which is consistent with the depth of the brittle-ductile transition in the area. On the Reykjanes Peninsula, brittle-ductile transition lies at 4–6 km depth, up-doming beneath the high-temperature geothermal fields (Flóvenz et al., 2022). Therefore, it is consistent with the depth extent of the Fagradalsfjall dyke.


4.4
Spatial and temporal evolution of the pre-eruption swarm
The ML 5.3 mainshock triggered a short aftershock sequence trending in the WSW-ENE direction along the rift zone (Fig. 5a). This aftershock sequence was not only located in the Fagradalsfjall area, but also affected the Krýsuvík fissure swarm to the east, triggering events with the same WSW-ENE trend. However, both segments are separated by an aseismic area of ∼5 km width (Fig. 4). Such a gap in seismicity, alternating with focused seismicity, is quite commonly observed on the Reykjanes Peninsula. It represents different types of deformation common in the rift zones with the alternation of seismically and aseismically released tectonic stress as discussed e.g., by Klein et al. (1977) and Einarsson (1991).
Subsequently, in the evening of 24 February 2021 (at 20:00 UTC), a swarm was initiated (Fig. 5b) north of the mainshock and extended until 2 March (Fig. 5c). It formed a narrow near-vertical band of events along the NE-SW oriented segment #1 (azimuth 45°) in the depth range of 3–6 km with sharp boundaries. The seismicity first propagated upwards in the SW direction with several reversals, trending similarly along the NE-SW axis. Migrating seismicity is usually attributed to two possible reasons: (a) magma propagation or (b) migration of magma-related fluids (Flóvenz et al., 2022). In Fagradalsfjall, the surface displacement favors direct magma movements and propagation of a magmatic dyke (Sigmundsson et al., 2021). This is also in agreement with other studies highlighting volcanic eruptions in the rift zones being often preceded by lateral migration of magma-filled dykes (e.g., Rubin, 1992; Belachew et al., 2011; Sigmundsson et al., 2015). From this point of view, the NE-SW migrating seismicity provides evidence on gradual dyke-front propagation due to magma movements and inflation/deflation of the dyke.
In the next stage, between 2 and 9 March, the seismicity re-activated the central part of the dyke path forming a triple junction around the subsequent eruption site. The dyke propagated southwestwards, and several bursts re-activated the rift zone to the WSW (Fig. 5d). Moreover, the seismic activity framed the U-shaped aseismic zone in the central part of the NE-SW trending dyke at 2–4 km depth (Fig. 3). The coincidence of the aseismic U-shaped zone, the largest surface displacement, and the proximity to the eruption site points to the magma accumulation at this place.
During the next stage, between 9 and 14 March, the swarm migrated further south, activating segment #3 (Fig. 2 and 5e). Meanwhile, almost no activity occurred in other segments. This southern dyke segment #3 was again nearly vertical, quite narrow, and well delimited. Compared to the northern dyke segment #1, its depth range of 2–5 km was slightly broader as well as its strike was 34° (Fig. 3), unlike 45° in segment #1. When it reached the southernmost tip of the dyke, it activated a short part of the southern WSW-trending branch of the rift zone. In the morning of 15 March, the activity jumped to the NE, moving back to the central part of the dyke path, and terminated near the future eruption site.
Finally, after four days of weak seismic activity (Fig. 2, 5f), the magma breached the surface on 19 March, resulting in the 2021 Fagradalsfjall eruption in the central part of the NE-SW-trending dyke, right above the SW edge of the U-shaped aseismic zone (Fig. 5e). A 6-month-lasting effusive lava outflow followed. (The detailed swarm evolution is also shown in Electronic supplement S4.)


4.5
Tectonic stress transfer, seismicity and lava outflow
Based on the spatiotemporal evolution of the 2021 Fagradalsfjall earthquake swarm and detailed analysis of the activity, we propose the following understanding of the pre-eruption processes.
The mainshock of 24 February 2021 triggered the short aftershock sequence to the WSW along the northern branch of the rift zone. This is indicated by the Coulomb stress modelling, which shows clear coincidence of the elevated CFS zone with the aftershock occurrence (Fig. 9). In the Fagradalsfjall area, the rift zone forms an anticlockwise step-over with an offset of about one kilometer, which coincides with the dyke trend and location (Fig. 8). Such a step-over, together with the left-lateral slip on the rift zone, generates an extension zone resulting in the crust weakening under tension. This feature is consistent with the pull-apart basin concept, confirmed also by modelling (e.g., Farangitakis et al., 2021), explaining the interactions between the strike-slip and extensional tectonics (Fossen, 2016). The pull-apart basin is limited to the distance between the faults and the step-over and is in a favorable position for the extensional or transtensional stress. Moreover, the transtensional setting generates greater surface deformation than the pure strike-slips, confirmed by modelling (Wu et al., 2009). The location of the Fagradalsfjall eruption site and the entire eruptive fissure of about 800 m length fits perfectly the fault step-over (Figs. 1, 8), which supports our hypothesis that the eruption was controlled by stress perturbations in the shallow crust. These issues were related to the ongoing left-lateral slip deviated by the anticlockwise step-over and the resulting zone of the extensional tectonics within the step-over. The Coulomb stress analysis also reveals that the mainshock could be responsible for initiating the following seismic swarm activity and the subsequent eruption by perturbing crustal stress and a present pocket of magma (Fig. 8).
The main NE-SW-propagating seismic activity relates to the magmatic dyke movements. This is supported by the systematic migration of seismicity, by the orientation of the activated segment along the maximum principal stress, and by the large magma-related deformation. The migration of seismicity maps the gradual dyke-front propagation: (i) first propagating back and forth in the northern part of the dyke path trending 45°, (ii) then activating the central part of the dyke, and (iii) finally moving to the south and activating the SW part of the dyke at an azimuth of 34°. The general trend of the dyke corresponds to the strike of the eruptive fissures on the Reykjanes Peninsula and is related to the extensional tectonics (Fig. 1). Slightly different angles of the northern (45°) and southern (34°) segments of the dyke can be related to different local settings and possible stress rotation in the vicinity of the oblique rift zone.
The rift zone trends WSW-ENE and is bounded from the north and the south by two parallel seismicity branches at a distance of ∼2 km. Both these branches were activated during previous swarms of 2017, 2019 and 2020 (Fig. 6). This highlights the unique character of the 2021 swarm, whose major part occurred along the NE-SW structure, which did not exist during the previous 2017–2020 swarm activities. This NE-SW seismicity accompanied the dyke propagation and intersected the related segment of the rift zone at an oblique angle (Fig. 6). The 2021 Fagradalsfjall eruption occurred at the intersection of the individual activated segments. Interestingly, this was the place where Hrubcová et al. (2021), based on the analysis of the 2017 swarm, revealed an emerging magmatic dyke, and where the aseismic U-shaped zone of the 2021 swarm was identified (Figs. 3 and 6). From this point of view, the Fagradalsfjall pre-eruption activity can be seen as the result of transtensional faulting leading to the volcanic eruption at the pull-apart step-over point.



5
Conclusions
We analyzed the 2021 Fagradalsfjall pre-eruption seismicity to trace the processes leading to the 2021 Fagradalsfjall eruption on the Reykjanes Peninsula, SW Iceland. We obtained over 30,000 automatically located earthquakes with magnitudes of ML 0–5.3 (24 February 2021 mainshock) using data from the local Reykjanet seismic network from 23 February to 20 March 2021.
Double-difference relocations indicate the activation of different fault segments of the transtensional rift zone on the Reykjanes Peninsula revealing interactions between tectonic and magmatic processes. We identified two main hypocenter clusters activating two fault systems: the main cluster of a NE-SW trend related to the magmatic dyke propagation and the extensional part of the rift zone, and the secondary WSW-ENE trending cluster activating the plate boundary axis. Both clusters intersected at the 2021 Fagradalsfjall eruption site. These results agree with relocated hypocenters of the preceding 2017, 2019 and 2020 swarms, showing two parallel WSW-ENE oriented branches (2 km apart) along the rift zone, coinciding with the subsidiary WSW-ENE trending cluster of the 2021 swarm. This points to the unique character of the 2021 swarm where the major activity occurred along the main NE-SW trending cluster, which did not exist in previous activities.
The main NE-SW propagating 2021 seismicity relates to the magmatic dyke movements. This is supported by the systematic migration of seismicity, by the orientation of the activated segment along the maximum principal stress, and by the large magma-related surface deformation. Though systematic, the 2021 dyke propagation was, however, complex: it started at the northern end migrating southwestwards, and when populating the southernmost dyke segment, jumping again to the central part of the dyke path where the effusive eruption eventually took place. Only one dyke segment was active at a time with continuous seismicity along the dyke, unlike the seismicity along the plate boundary axis that was characterized by several rapid earthquake bursts.
The ML 5.3 mainshock shows the N-S striking fault planes interpreted as the right-lateral antithetic Riedel shears that accommodate the left-lateral slip along the rift zone. This mainshock was immediately followed by a short aftershock sequence in the WSW-ENE rift zone and subsequently (eight hours later) by a small swarm in the northern dyke segment. Coulomb Failure Stress modelling shows that the mainshock could have triggered not only the aftershock sequence but also the earthquake swarm along the dyke. The almost 4 weeks long migrating nature of the NE-SW oriented dyke suggests that the earthquakes were caused by magma movements. The dyke breached the surface on 19 March 2021, right above the location of the aseismic area detected in the 2017 and 2021 swarms.
The location of the eruptive fissure precisely coincides with the anticlockwise step-over of the rift zone, forming a pull-apart basin structure in the area of eruption. This shows that the magma erupted at the place of crustal weakening under tension. The long-term left-lateral slip along the plate boundary caused the redistribution of the crustal stress at the future eruption site.

Introduction
On Mars, sediment budgets are fundamental for understanding landscape evolution related to climate, weather, and geologic history. The majority of Mars' recent geological past has been largely driven by aeolian processes (Sagan and Bagnold, 1975; Diniega et al., 2021). Features, such as yardangs and stabilized dunefields provide a record of past climate (Banks et al., 2018; Urso et al., 2018). Active ripples and dunes provide a record of current surface winds (Runyon et al., 2017a; Silvestro et al., 2020; Bridges et al., 2017; Vaz et al., 2017). Dunefields also provide a record of geomorphic change from interactions with volatile cycles (Diniega et al., 2017; Chojnacki et al., 2021) and may record changes in wind regimes due to Mars' obliquity changes (Runyon et al., 2017b).
A sediment budget is defined as the difference between the quantity (mass or volume) of sediment entering an area of interest, such as a dunefield, versus the quantity of sediment leaving the same area [Equation (1); where ΔS is the change in sediment storage, I is the sediment inputs (influx), and E is the sediment outputs (efflux)].

Sediment budgets are vital for determining the degree of, and controls on, erosion or deposition processes. On Earth, sediment budgets are fundamental for understanding geologic impacts to natural resources and infrastructure. Sediment budgets can be influenced in whole or in part by naturally occurring physical processes, such as volcanic eruptions, debris flows, and fluvial, glacial, or aeolian sediment transport. These controls on sediment budgets are applicable in geomorphologically-active regions of planetary bodies, such as Mars, Venus, Earth, Europa, and Titan.
There are two common methods geomorphologists use to determine a sediment budget: flux-based and morphological, which we term the in-situ and remote sensing methods, respectively, in this paper (Table 1
). The former approach determines the budget by making mass-based measurements of the sediment flux variables I and E to solve for the ΔS variable on the left side of Equation (1). The latter method determines the budget from remote sensing topographic change detection of volumetric changes in sediment storage. The remote sensing method directly measures the ΔS variable but presents a problem, because it provides an estimate of the difference between I and E but does not quantify I or E individually unless they are known or assumed to be zero.
Geomorphologists refer to a “closed sediment budget” when I-E is shown to equal ΔS after making the necessary conversions between sediment mass and volume in a field experiment for a river, aeolian dunefield, hillslope, or alluvial fan, for example. In practice, however, sediment budgets rarely do close, because of measurement errors and uncertainties, and differences in the temporal and spatial sampling resolution and integration. On Earth, an increasingly common approach to attempt to close a sediment budget is to make mass-based sediment flux measurements of I and E and compare them to remote sensing change detection of ΔS (e.g., Erwin et al., 2012; Grams et al., 2013, 2018). Doing so can provide powerful insight into landscape evolution for academic and theoretical purposes, as well as practical engineering and resource management applications. Practically speaking, the comparison of in-situ and remote sensing sediment budgets on Earth, where both techniques are available to investigators, may provide insight into potential errors with the remote sensing technique, which is the only method currently available for sediment budget quantification on planetary bodies outside Earth.
Currently, only the remote sensing method is available to investigate sediment budgets on Mars. Remote sensing of bedform processes, in some cases from multi-temporal image time series, is used to estimate sand fluxes from measurements of dune migration rates and dune heights on Mars (Bridges et al., 2012; Chojnacki et al., 2015, 2017, 2018, 2019; Runyon et al., 2017a,b; Roback et al., 2020, 2022). Roback et al. (2020) estimated components of the morphological sediment budget for a dunefield on Mars with HiRISE images and digital terrain models by measuring dune migration rates and the volume of sand trapped in a crater located downwind of the dunefield relative to the expected volume of sand eroded from the dunefield. However, change detection of repeat topographic data is not yet commonly employed on Mars (Sutton et al., 2022), though can be performed with data returned from the High Resolution Imaging Science Experiment (HiRISE; McEwen et al., 2007) using photogrammetry methods (Beyer, 2015; Beyer et al., 2018). In contrast to Mars, investigators on Earth use both methods. The remote sensing method is limited in its accuracy because sediment fluxes are inferred but are not directly measured. Additionally, remote sensing sediment budgets can have large uncertainties owing to compensating sediment erosion and deposition on the lee and slipfaces of migrating dunes during the inter-survey period that while accurate for the time period examined may mask otherwise considerable sediment fluxes through the study area (e.g., the bypass fraction of sediment not deposited on slipfaces, sensu Mohrig and Smith, 1996). Uncertainties associated with the remote sensing method can be so large that the derived sediment budgets are often indeterminate – that is, they cannot reliably distinguish whether an area is undergoing erosion or deposition – without additional corroboration using in-situ measurements as shown by studies on Earth (e.g., Bangen et al., 2014a; Grams and Schmidt, 2005).
Despite the fundamental importance of sediment budgets for planetary science, and the widespread use of the remote sensing and in-situ methods for quantifying sediment budgets across geologic domains on Earth, there has been surprisingly little research on how well the sediment budgets produced by these two techniques reconcile with one another. For ongoing and future geomorphic research on Mars, this means there is a general need to further our knowledge of sediment budgets and highlights the lack of quantitative understanding of uncertainties for sediment budgets measured with remote sensing. Here we use a concise background review to explore: 1) how in-situ and remote sensing sediment budgets are typically constructed for aeolian dunefields; and 2) how the combination of the two methods is used to evaluate sediment budget errors in the fluvial geomorphology discipline on Earth, where the approach is commonly put into practice for river science applications. We then evaluate the relative differences of in-situ and remote sensing sediment budgets for a terrestrial analog aeolian dunefield case study. Our overall goal is to frame a path forward for addressing shortcomings of remote sensing sediment budgets in extraterrestrial aeolian settings like Mars where in-situ methods are not currently tractable.

Using in-situ measurements to reconcile remote sensing sediment budgets (or vice versa as shown in Fig. 2

In aeolian environments on Earth, these approaches have been primarily used in coastal dunefields that have a clear on- or along-shore wind directional regime and thus an upwind sediment supply from ocean sediment deposits such as sandy beaches.
The most conceptually straightforward method for quantifying a sediment budget is through in-situ, or direct, measurement of sediment fluxes. In terrestrial aeolian dunefields, these measurements are typically collected using a vertical array of sediment catchers placed at the upwind and downwind site boundaries. While conceptually simple, the in-situ technique suffers from two disadvantages. First, the approach requires significant financial and logistical resources, as equipment must be obtained, deployed, and maintained, often in remote sites. Sediment traps, for example, must be visited regularly to record data and to be emptied when filled with sediment. This is a hindrance in extraterrestrial research, where deploying and maintaining in-situ equipment can be impossible.
Secondly, the accumulation of measurement error through time is non-trivial; any measurement of sediment flux may contain inherent error or bias, and those errors rapidly accumulate as the number of measurements increases. Several factors can generate in-situ measurement error, including non-uniform sediment flux across a site, errors in upscaling discrete measurements to whole-site areas and longer time frames, and sediment mass transport calculation uncertainties (Ellis et al., 2009; Webb et al., 2019; Zobeck et al., 2003). These errors can grow so large through time that simply determining whether a site is undergoing erosion or deposition may not be possible. As an example, Fig. 2 details the accumulation of error in measurements of fluvial sediment in the Colorado River in Grand Canyon from 2002 to 2010 (Grams et al., 2013; Topping and Wright, 2016). In the example, error accumulates through time for the primary in-situ method and the remote sensing method is used as a secondary check to reset the sediment budget errors to zero three times during the calendar year from 2004 to 2005 (Fig. 2). However, note that without the check from the remote sensing method after 2005, the uncertainty in the in-situ method eventually grows so large that from 2008 to 2010 the budget cannot be characterized as net erosional or depositional (Fig. 2).
Given the logistical difficulties and potentially large accumulating errors in quantifying sediment budgets using in-situ techniques, many researchers turn to remote sensing change detection to indirectly estimate the sediment budget of an area. This is an inverse technique (Ashmore and Church, 1998; Church, 2006; Vericat et al., 2017; Sankey et al., 2018a,b), whereby the volume of eroded or deposited sediment required to drive observed changes in surface topography is computed. To begin, at least two topographic surveys of an area of interest are required. These can be collected by a variety of methods, including photogrammetry, lidar, sonar, GPS, or total station surveys.  While methodologically straightforward, the remote sensing approach also suffers from significant drawbacks related to: (i) potential underestimation of sediment fluxes and (ii) measurement uncertainty. With regard to the former, the technique infers, but does not directly measure, sediment fluxes. The volume changes that are computed on a per-pixel basis from sequential DEMs thus represent a minimum estimate of sediment flux during the inter-survey period, a phenomenon recognized in many environments (e.g., Erwin et al., 2012; Kasprak et al., 2019; Lindsay and Ashmore, 2002). This is because offsetting volumes of erosion and deposition may combine to produce relatively little elevation change (and thus a small remote sensing-based flux estimate), when in fact larger volumes of sediment were transiting through an area over the inter-survey period. Given the potential for compensating erosion and deposition to mask what are actually large sediment fluxes, it is advisable to reconcile any remote sensing sediment budget using in-situ data. For aeolian dunefields, this is done with in-situ measurements of I and E.
In addition to the potential underestimation of sediment fluxes due to compensating erosion and deposition, remote sensing estimates of sediment budgets are also prone to errors from measurement uncertainty. The constituent DEMs from which elevation changes, and volumetric sediment budgets, are derived each contain varying degrees of measurement uncertainty. This uncertainty results primarily from (i) instrument error (in the case of satellite sensor, lidar, GPS, total station, etc.; see Bangen et al., 2014, 2014a, 2016 & Wheaton et al., 2010), and (ii) interpolation error that results from generating a raster DEM from native point-based measurements of elevation (Kaplinski et al., 2017). The result of these DEM errors is that any elevation changes used to quantify a site-scale sediment budget must be evaluated to determine whether those changes are true and driven by geomorphic processes, or whether they are spurious changes arising from survey error, or ‘noise’. Error estimation techniques based on survey quality and terrain complexity have been recently developed (Bangen et al., 2016; Kasprak et al., 2015) and applied in dunefield studies (Kasprak et al., 2017; Sankey et al., 2018a,b) though not in extraterrestrial studies to our knowledge. These techniques can aid in thresholding, or removing, potentially erroneous elevation changes from sediment budget analyses based on the magnitude of change by removing very low-magnitude elevation changes within the instrument's measurement tolerance, or as a spatially variable function of surveyed surface complexity.


3
Analog case study – investigating sediment budget errors using chasma floor dunefields

3.1
Chasma floor dunefields on Earth and Mars: morphology and setting
Chasma floor dunefields on Earth and Mars provide a useful test case to evaluate aeolian dunefield sediment budget errors because they respond to boundary conditions of wind regime and sediment supply (Figs. 3 and 4

). For example, the physiography of canyon environments often drives chasma-parallel wind directions that can be inferred from chasma orientation and dune morphology. The dunes vary in size and composition owing to upwind sediment source areas (Figs. 3 and 4). Here we present a case study for quantitative sediment budgeting using sites from Valles Marineris on Mars and the Grand Canyon on Earth. Currently, only the remote sensing method is available to estimate sediment budgets for dunefields on Mars. However, analogous chasma floor aeolian dunefields are common within Grand Canyon, Arizona, USA on Earth (Fig. 4; Sankey et al., 2018a,b) where both methods for estimating sediment budgets are feasible.

3.1.1
Chasma floor dunefields in Valles Marineris, Mars
Dunes within the Valles Marineris rift system of Mars are associated with a variety of landforms that serve as potential sediment sources (Chojnacki et al., 2014a,b; Boazman et al., 2021). Prior work has indicated that Valles Marineris dunefields are likely derived from a variety of local and regional (intra-rift) sediment sources (Lucchitta et al., 1992; Chojnacki et al., 2010, 2014a, 2014b; Fenton et al., 2014; Boazman et al., 2021). Spectral and thermal mapping has revealed the principal sand dune sources for the region are Noachian-aged lower wall materials composed of primary (igneous) minerals and glasses. Other locations show evidence for sediment derivation from adjacent Early Hesperian-aged, hydrated sulfate-bearing sedimentary layered units (Chojnacki et al., 2014b). This finding indicates sediment stored in these sedimentary units act as secondary sources.
Among the different dunefield classes, floor dunefields display the most variability in Valles Marineris dune morphology, having sand sheet, star, echo, and linear dunes, including both compound and complex variations (Fig. 3) (Hayward et al., 2007). In the simplest case, barchanoid, barchan, and transverse dunes develop on central floors as they conform to a unidirectional wind regime (Fig. 3). More commonly, topographic elements, such as walls or landslides, disrupt simple dunes, instead forming echo and linear duneforms (Fig. 3). Converging or diverging multidirectional wind regimes can also develop as regional-scale katabatic wind patterns interact with and drain into the rift (Rafkin and Michaels, 2003; Toigo and Richardson, 2003; Fenton et al., 2014) developing falling dunes draped on wall slopes and star dunes on central floors (Fig. 3; Chojnacki et al., 2010, 2014a).
Sediment supply varies across Valles Marineris and is largely dependent on the wind regime complexity and sand source (Chojnacki et al., 2014b; Fenton et al., 2014). Supply-limited conditions predictably form barchans which migrate at relatively high rates (e.g., Ganges Chasma; (Fenton et al., 2014)). High sediment-supply dunefields develop in constructive wind regimes where larger magnitude bedform sizes and sand fluxes occur (e.g., Juventae Chasma; (Chojnacki et al., 2014a,b)).


3.1.2
Chasma floor dunefields in Grand Canyon, Earth
Fifty-seven floor dunefields occur in Grand Canyon along the margins of the Colorado River, downwind of river sandbars, with aeolian sand overlying other topographic surfaces that are characteristic of deep-chasma landscapes such as debris fans, talus slopes, and terraces (Fig. 4; Sankey et al., 2018a). Change detection of high-resolution topographic surveys and analysis of weather station data have been previously employed at several Grand Canyon floor dunefields to characterize their wind directional regime and sediment supply characteristics (Sankey et al., 2018a,b). These dunefields are supplied with sand transferred by wind from contemporary river sandbars. The sandbars are themselves formed and maintained with sediment from the Colorado River (Schmidt, 1990). In the simplest case, floor dunefields in Grand Canyon occur as transverse or barchanoid dunes that form in a unidirectional wind regime that transports sand from an upwind fluvial sandbar source area to the downwind dunefield. In this scenario, the predominant wind direction follows the path of the canyon, either in the upriver or downriver direction. Under more complex directional wind regimes, floor dunefields form and are resupplied with sand from bi-modal, canyon-parallel wind directions that alternately transport sand from up- and downriver sandbars. Sankey et al. (2018a,b) found that dunefields in Grand Canyon can be classified into three general categories of sediment budgets based on sediment supply and wind directional regimes:

•
Aeolian dunefields with an active sediment supply and a unimodal wind regime tend to exhibit a net depositional sediment budget (e.g., Soap dunefield in Fig. 4).


•
Aeolian dunefields without an active sediment supply, but which are marked by a unimodal wind regime, tend to exhibit a net erosional sediment budget (e.g., Lees dunefield in Fig. 4).


•
Aeolian dunefields with, or without, an active sediment supply and a multimodal wind directional regime often exhibit an equilibrium sediment budget (e.g., Fossil dunefield in Fig. 4).

Equation (7) calculates the absolute value of the relative percent difference between sediment budgets derived by the two methods. In this analog case study, we evaluate the sediment budget relative percent difference using remote sensing and in-situ measurements for a dunefield in GC with the simplest of sediment supply and wind regime scenarios: at a site without active sediment supply and a unimodal wind regime. Our objective is to demonstrate the sediment budget relative percent differences for this simple scenario to help shed light on the potential magnitudes and complexities of sediment budget errors that might occur under these and more complex wind and sediment supply regimes elsewhere on Earth and Mars.


3.3
Analog case study site and methods
We deployed sediment flux monitoring equipment for this case study and sequentially conducted remote sensing surveys at a dunefield located in Grand Canyon along the Colorado River at Lees Ferry, Arizona. The Lees dunefield (Fig. 4) consists of barchanoid dunes that form in a unidirectional wind regime that formerly transported sand from an upwind fluvial sandbar source area to the downwind dunefield. Glen Canyon Dam, which was constructed in 1963 approximately 15 km upstream of Lees Ferry, allows for very little passage of river sediment from the Lake Powell reservoir to the downstream Colorado River in Grand Canyon. As a result, the Lees dunefield is sediment-starved, with limited external sediment supply from the adjacent river sandbar. The annual windy season, when most of the aeolian transport occurs in Grand Canyon is from February through April (East et al., 2016; Sankey et al., 2018a,b). The sediment budget time period for this analog case study was designed to span one of these windy seasons in the spring of 2019.

(2019) also detected different magnitudes of topographic changes in dunefields in the Grand Canyon when change detection was performed for elevation data interpolated at 0.1 vs. 1.0 m pixel resolution. DEM resolution for geomorphology investigations on Mars and other planetary bodies is determined by the native resolution of the images from a particular platform and sensor (e.g., HiRISE) used to derive the raster elevation dataset. However, we did find large differences between the remote sensing and in-situ method results for some of the more conservative significance thresholding approaches when the remote sensing data were resampled at the 0.1-10 m pixel resolutions (Fig. 5ab).

This means that the potential for compensating elevation changes – where dunes within some portions of the dunefield increase in height while others decrease – will be low, and divergence in flux magnitudes (i.e., I-E) will be small and/or negative (Lindsay and Ashmore, 2002; Erwin et al., 2012; Kasprak et al., 2019) though the amount of apparent erosion estimated by ΔS

Remote Sensing

However, sites with variable sediment supply, may both erode and aggrade (Sankey et al., 2018a,b) and have greater divergence in flux magnitudes, but also have larger remote sensing sediment budget errors as erosion and deposition over the survey interval can occur within the same areas or pixels.
Dunefields that have a unimodal wind directional regime have a clear upwind source area which may or may not – as is the case with Lees – have a supply of available sediment. The consistent directionality of sediment transport provides a higher level of confidence in in-situ measurements of sediment flux relative to sites with greater sediment supply or multimodal wind direction regime. This is because as sediment supply increases, the potential for in-situ measurement error also increases due to difficulties in capturing multiple transport pathways through a site with sediment catchers and accurately upscaling point measurements to the site scale (Zobeck et al., 2003). Multimodal wind directional regimes further complicate apparent topographic changes as the relationships between sediment transport direction and bedform orientation are complex (Rubin and Hunter, 1987) and compensating bedform elevation changes can thus be large, meaning remote sensing sediment budgets less accurately capture true sediment flux (Lindsay and Ashmore, 2002; Erwin et al., 2012; Kasprak et al., 2019). Additionally, in multimodal wind regimes, trapping of sediment by in-situ sensors less accurately reflects site-scale sediment, resulting in more error in the computation of site-scale flux (Zobeck et al., 2003; Webb et al., 2019).
Our study focuses on evaluating remote sensing sediment budgets relative to the in-situ method, as this is the more relevant comparison for extraterrestrial geomorphology where remote sensing methods are more feasible. Thus, we don't for example, evaluate the effects of different parameterizations for estimating I and E from in-situ sediment transport data (e.g., Equations (2)-(5)). Nor do we explicitly evaluate different sample sizes or sampling locations or frequencies for the in-situ flux measurements which are necessarily integrated across space and time and extrapolated to the surveyed dimensions of the dunefield. We similarly don't evaluate different approaches for converting sediment flux values from units of mass to volume. Explicit consideration of these different sources of uncertainty for the measurement and calculation of in-situ sediment fluxes is warranted for future research, particularly for geomorphology on Earth, where it can be more relevant to use remote sensing methods as a validation (e.g., Fig. 2; Grams et al., 2013) of differing estimations of sediment budgets from in-situ methods.
Conceptually, we propose that the case study dunefield provides an endmember, or lower-bound, scenario with simple site topography and wind regime, and no sediment supply, for the relative error of remote sensing sediment budgets for chasma floor dunefields on Mars (Fig. 6
). As complexity within topography, sediment supply, and wind regime increase, we expect sediment budget errors to increase. Though our conceptual understanding of these factors provides a way forward for interpreting extraterrestrial sediment budgets (Fig. 6), sediment budget relative percent differences at many more analog sites on Earth with a range of complexities are needed to characterize the full range of potential errors that might be expected for remote sensing sediment budgets on Mars.
We emphasize the potential value of future studies on Earth that measure sediment budgets using both in-situ and remote sensing techniques at analog sites with a diverse suite of wind regimes, sediment supplies, and topographic settings as well as dunefield sizes. Comparison of migration rates and dune sizes for a selection of dunefields on Mars and analog sites on Earth indicates that the Grand Canyon Lees dunefield is a reasonable analog but also that there is a need to evaluate a broader variety of analog dunefields as well (Fig. 7
). By computing sediment budget relative percent differences across sites, relationships could be developed between site characteristics, scale, and the potential error in 
Δ

Remote

, which is the only tractable method for sediment budgeting on Mars at present. We are not aware of any investigations that have quantified Martian aeolian dunefield sediment budgets with detailed analyses of measurement uncertainties and sediment budget error. Moreover, we are not aware of any previous investigations that have compared sediment budgets for Martian dunefields to analogs on Earth using the remote sensing methodology currently available for Mars, or the in-situ methodology commonly employed on Earth that may one day be feasible for Mars. By comparing sediment budgets derived from in-situ measurements of sediment fluxes and from remote sensing measurements at many more analog sites on Earth, the aeolian research community could gain an understanding of the errors of the remote sensing method which is used by investigators on Mars. This improved understanding could also enhance the ability to quantify aeolian abrasion from remote sensing and its role in landscape evolution on Mars (Bridges et al., 2012; Chojnacki et al., 2018). Such comparative planetology research would improve our ability to quantify sediment budgets on Mars – and, in the future, other planetary environments where high-resolution topographic data are or will be available – as well as directly improve investigators' ability to interpret Martian landscape evolution related to climate, weather, and geologic history.

Introduction
The Earth's inner core was first discovered by Lehmann (1936) through analysis of the P-wave outer core shadow zone. It is a solid sphere composed of an iron and nickel alloy with a radius of approximately 1217.5 km. Despite its remote location, the inner core has an essential role in the origin of many dynamic processes; in particular, its solidification and the resulting release of latent heat, drive convection in the outer core and thus sustain Earth's magnetic field. This latent heat also contributes to the heat flux at the core mantle boundary and represents an important driver of mantle convection.
Although mineral physics provides us with estimates of the composition and crystalline properties of the inner core, only seismology provides direct measurements of its elastic structure. One of the most striking observations is that the inner core appears to be anisotropic, whereby the velocity of a seismic wave varies depending on its direction of propagation. In the inner core, this anomalous structure is observed in the fact that waves travelling aligned to Earth's rotation axis arrive earlier than waves travelling in the equatorial plane. Later studies showed that these body wave observations are best matched by cylindrical anisotropy (Morelli et al., 1986), which also explains observations of anomalous zonal splitting of inner core sensitive free oscillations (Woodhouse et al., 1986).
As global seismic data coverage increased, seismic investigations began to resolve 3D lateral variations and radial heterogeneity in the inner core. Hemispherical differences were first proposed by Tanaka and Hamaguchi (1997) and later confirmed by many other studies (Niu and Wen 2001; Waszek and Deuss 2011; Lythgoe et al. 2014; Burdick et al. 2019). These hemispherical differences are characterised by a eastern hemisphere with weak anisotropy and fast isotropic velocity, and a western hemisphere with strong anisotropy and low isotropic velocity. The outermost layer of the inner core has been proposed as isotropic, both in the east and west (Wen and Niu, 2002; Waszek and Deuss, 2011). Furthermore, an innermost inner core (IMIC) with a different fast or slow symmetry axes may exist, although the details remain unconfirmed regarding the exact direction of the slow axes, its regional distribution or its origins (Beghein and Trampert, 2003; Ishii and Dziewoński, 2003; Sun and Song, 2008b; Lythgoe et al., 2014; Frost and Romanowicz, 2019). Sun and Song (2008b) produced an impressive early 3D tomographic model of the inner core using differential travel times. Their model recovered many of the main features in the inner core that we still see today, including isotropic quasi hemispheres, an inner most inner core and strong anisotropy in one quasi hemisphere.
One limitation in interpreting seismic body wave observations in terms of distinct regional features (like hemispheres) is that the resultant models strongly depend on the chosen parameterisation. Furthermore, trade-offs exist between different structures depending on the model parameterisation. Not accounting for lateral variations may explain why some studies find a sharp change in anisotropy at an apparent IMIC (Stephenson et al., 2020; Frost and Romanowicz, 2019), while others find a gradual IMIC boundary, if it exists at all (Lythgoe et al., 2014). In addition, hemispheres are often assumed to be defined by meridians and features such as the innermost inner core usually have a constant radius, which may be overly simplifying their shapes.
Another major challenge when imaging the inner core is removing the influence of mantle heterogeneity. A particular subset of raypaths, travelling from the South Sandwich Islands (SSI) to Alaska, have been noted to travel anomalously fast. It has been debated to what extent these travel times reflect inner core structure or mantle structure (Tkalčić 2010; Frost et al. 2020; Brett and Deuss 2020). To address the issue of mantle heterogeneity, we use multiple tomographic mantle models to assess unaccounted for mantle structure, and we develop inner core models which both include and exclude the South Sandwich Islands data.
In this study, we apply a transdimensional Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) inversion technique (Bodin and Sambridge, 2009) to a large high-quality body wave data set to make a 3D model of inner core velocity and anisotropy. We consider our model to be the next step in inner core tomography, with the main difference that we use a transdimensional Monte Carlo approach and that we can now utilise significantly more data due to the increased coverage of seismic stations and events. The advantage of a transdimensional MCMC methodology over an inversion using a static parameterisation, is that the parameterisation of the model space evolves with the Markov chain and is not predetermined. Thus, the model parameterisation is driven by the data itself, with no prior assumptions on the parameterisation, such as the existence of an IMIC or hemispheres. Previously, Burdick et al. (2019) and Pejić et al. (2019) used a transdimensional MCMC approach to image a single layer of inner core velocity and attenuation respectively. These previous studies were 2D spherical surface inversions and in this paper we go further by conducting the first fully 3D transdimensional MCMC for the inner core, which allows us to resolve jointly for both lateral and radial variations in P-wave anisotropy, which is essential to answering questions on the mechanisms and causes of anisotropy in the inner core.

Markov chain Monte Carlo
We then use Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) to sample the posterior probability distribution of our data-model system (Cowles and Carlin, 1996). For a given prior probability and data, we evaluate the forward problem over many proposed models, with each proposed model related to the previous model with a small random perturbation. The Metropolis-Hastings criteria ensure that accepted models are representative of the posterior probability distribution.

4.5
Transdimensional model proposals
In a traditional MCMC inversion the parameterisation of the model space is static (i.e. the number and locations of the Voronoi cells remains the same across all iterations) and defined prior to the inversion. Thus, only the model parameters a, b and c within each Voronoi cell would be perturbed. However, in our transdimensional MCMC, the data defines how the model is parameterised through perturbing the number and locations of the Voronoi cells. Thus, the transdimensional method samples models with different complexity (i.e. number of model parameters and volumes) resulting in an ensemble of varying dimensioned models that plausibly explain the observations. This is implemented as a ‘reductionist’ methodology, i.e. if the dataset can be fit equally well with 10 volumes instead of 11, then the final ensemble will include more models with 10 volumes than 11.
The velocity perturbations to the model parameters a, b and c are described in Appendix B.1. The additional perturbations to the parameterisation of the model space require three more perturbation types: move (moving cells), birth (generating new cells), and death (removing cells) and are described in detail in Appendix B.2-B.4.



5
Ensemble analysis
We applied the transdimensional MCMC algorithm (section 4.5) to our data (section 2) and ran 20 chains for 4,000,000 iterations with an acceptance rate (the percentage of accepted perturbations) of 30.5%. Fig. 3
a shows how the misfit changes as a function of iteration in the inversion for all 20 chains. The misfit drops rapidly in the first 200,000 iterations before reaching a misfit minimum; the transdimensional algorithm then samples models around this minimum value.
Once the inversion has completed the desired number of iterations, the models are collected into an ensemble from which statistics are calculated. We remove the influence of the starting model by excluding the first third of all iterations in the ensemble of models; the so-called ‘burn in’. It is also common practice to ‘thin’ the chain by only retaining every 100th model, which ensures that each model in an ensemble is independent. Following ‘burn in’ and ‘thinning’ leaves a final ensemble of 533,380 models. For further discussion regarding appropriate values for the ‘burn in’ and ‘thinning’ we refer the reader to Cowles and Carlin (1996).
For an MCMC investigation, it is important to ensure that the model sampling has converged, whereby the model space has been sufficiently explored and the models are no longer evolving substantially. To assess convergence, we examine the number of volumes in each chain as a function of iteration (Fig. 3b). The number of volumes across all chains drops rapidly within the first 10,000 iterations, as the starting model is refined and Voronoi cells which do not reduce misfit are removed. After this initial reduction of volumes, the MCMC algorithm better assesses the noise level within the data, and the number of volumes across all chains starts to increase before flattening out after 1,000,000 iterations. For the next 3,000,000 iterations, the mean number of volumes across all chains does not change substantially, implying convergence. After convergence, the average model misfit has reduced from 1.0 to 0.55, and the models have between 23 and 38 volumes.
We also investigate the average hierarchical noise parameters for each data type (section 4.3) from the 533,380 models in our final ensemble (Fig. 3c). As expected, the PKPcd-PKPdf data has the lowest noise level with 0.29 s on average of uncertainty in each measurement, followed by PKPbc-PKPdf data with a noise level of 0.63 s. Finally, the PKPab-PKPdf data and absolute PKPdf data show the largest levels of noise with similar values of approximately 0.95 s. Thus, the hierarchical sampling found the PKPcd-PKPdf data to have the lowest noise level, and will fit those observations more closely than the PKPab-PKPdf and absolute PKPdf data. From this analysis we expect that the top of the inner core is the best resolved region of our model due to the low noise level in the PKPcd-PKPdf data and the fact that we have more data sensitive to the top of the inner core than the centre of the inner core.

6.1
Isotropic hemispheres
Our model confirms the previously found hemispherical pattern with seismic P-waves travelling anomalously fast in the ‘eastern hemisphere’ of the inner core and anomalously slow in the ‘western hemisphere’. This is evident in maps of equatorial velocity throughout the inner core (Fig. 4
a-c), and at the top of the inner core in isotropic velocity (Fig. 4g). The hemispherical pattern is also clearly visible in cross sections through the equatorial plane (Fig. 5

a,c). This is in agreement with numerous previous studies (Tanaka and Hamaguchi 1997; Niu and Wen 2001; Waszek and Deuss 2011; Lythgoe et al. 2014; Burdick et al. 2019; Brett and Deuss 2020). We avoid describing the hemisphere boundaries using single meridians because the hemisphere boundaries are not straight lines through the poles; this is most visible in the equatorial velocity at the ICB around southern Africa and Hawaii (Fig. 4a.)
It is interesting to note that the hemispherical pattern in the equatorial velocity (Fig. 5a and 6a) persists and the magnitude of the equatorial velocity increases with depth in the eastern hemisphere. The advantage of our use of the transdimensional approach, is that we are not limited to simple hemispherical shapes anymore and so are now able to identify regional heterogeneity within the hemispheres. Further complexity is particularly visible in the meridional cross section (Fig. 6a), which reveals that the boundary separating the fast and slow equatorial velocities appears sharp and undulating. Some faster equatorial velocities associated with the eastern hemisphere encroach on the slower velocities of the western hemisphere. These new observations would be challenging to identify robustly without using a transdimensional methodology, as it would be difficult to know the extent to which the final model was influenced by the initial fixed parameterisation.
Comparing our model of the equatorial velocity to that of Burdick et al. (2019) we see good overall agreement in the location of the hemisphere boundaries, but with some extra complexity, this is due to the fact that we also solve for the 3D velocity structure and have more data both of which will influence the location of the boundaries at the ICB.
The hemispherical pattern in the isotropic velocity is present until about 60-170 km depth below the ICB (Fig. 4g, 5c and 6c), with boundaries between slow ‘west’ and fast ‘east’ located approximately at 170∘W and 30∘E in broad agreement with previous studies (Tanaka and Hamaguchi 1997; Waszek and Deuss 2011; Burdick et al. 2019). The reason that the isotropic velocity difference does not persist deeper in the inner core, is because the isotropic velocity is a Voigt average of the velocities in all directions. Although the hemispherical variations persist in the equatorial velocity with depth, the contribution of anisotropy (i.e. higher polar velocities) causes the isotropic velocity to lose its hemispherical pattern deeper than 60-170 km below the ICB (Fig. 7
a).


6.2
Anisotropic zone
In agreement with previous studies (i.e. Tanaka and Hamaguchi 1997; Niu and Wen 2001; Lythgoe et al. 2014; Brett and Deuss 2020), our model also contains a strong anisotropic zone in the west where inner core seismic P-waves travelling in the north-south or polar direction travel faster than waves that travel in the east-west or equatorial direction. The lateral extent of the western anisotropic zone is clearly visible in maps of the anisotropic velocity difference (Fig. 4n-o) at 400 and 800 km radius and also in cross-sections through our model (Fig. 5e and 6e). The inner core displays very little anisotropy near the ICB (Fig. 4m), with the exception of a strong patch with high uncertainty around South America, similar in location to a high uncertainty region found in Pejić et al. (2019).
A 1D profile through our model (Fig. 7a) furthermore shows that indeed anisotropy is weak at the top of the inner core (0 to 1%) and confirms strong anisotropy to be located within the western hemisphere approximately between 50 and 1100 km radius, and only weak anisotropy (

The radius of the transition to strong anisotropy in this region occurs between 1170 km and 1050 km (Fig. 7a). It is difficult to define more precisely this radius due to a lack of raypaths with turning points between 1110 km and 1060 km (Blom et al., 2015), resulting in a partial null space. This lack of data is reflected in the standard deviation (Fig. 5f), which shows a broad region of high uncertainty at the top of the anisotropic zone.

Tanaka and Hamaguchi (1997) described the anisotropic zone as being a ‘quasi-hemisphere’, i.e. it does not precisely span 180∘ of longitude. Indeed, we also observe that the anisotropic zone does not span 180∘ but runs between 170∘W and 30∘E (Fig. 5e), spanning a width of 200∘ in broad agreement with previous models (Sun and Song 2008a; Irving and Deuss 2011; Lythgoe et al. 2014).
Most importantly, because of our transdimensional approach we do not prescribe simple hemispherical shapes; this enabled us to find that the anisotropic zone does not continue all the way to the south pole. Instead, we observe for the first time that the western anisotropic zone is largely confined to the northern hemisphere (Fig. 6e). The anisotropy at the South pole of the inner core at 800 km radius is 2% with an uncertainty of 1.5%, while the anisotropy around North America is 8% with an uncertainty of 2% (Fig. 6e) meaning that within the bounds of uncertainty in our model the South pole has significantly lower anisotropy than the region around North America. This regional feature would have been difficult to map using traditional seismic tomography employing fixed parameterisations, and has important implications for models of inner core growth (section 7). Given that this region of strong anisotropy does not span half the inner core in either longitude or latitude, we use the descriptor of an ‘anisotropic zone’ (instead of hemisphere).
We conducted a resolution test, to ensure the concentration of anisotropy in the northern part of the western hemisphere was not an artefact of imperfect data coverage. To do this, we ran an inversion using synthetic data for a known synthetic model, containing simple hemispheres (with 8% anisotropy and 0% equatorial velocity in the west and 0% anisotropy and 2% equatorial velocity in the east) spanning all latitudes and a spherical IMIC (with 0.5% anisotropy and 1% equatorial velocity) located at the centre of the model (Figs. S9-S11). From this model we generated synthetic data using our real raypaths and added realistic Gaussian noise. The same transdimensional inversion was then conducted on the synthetic data as for the real data. We reproduced all major features from the synthetic model reliably (Figs. S12-S15), including an anisotropic hemisphere across all latitudes. This confirms that if the anisotropic region in the west of the inner core spanned all latitudes our data would be able to recover this feature.
We also ran a separate inversion excluding the particular subset of raypaths travelling from the South Sandwich Islands to Alaska (Figs. S16-S19). These raypaths appear to travel anomalously fast, and it has been debated to what extent these travel times reflect regional-scale inner core structure versus mantle contamination (Tkalčić 2010; Frost et al. 2020; Brett and Deuss 2020). Our model excluding SSI data shows the same main features, in particular that the western anisotropic zone is still located primarily in the northern hemisphere. Thus, we conclude that the effect of the SSI data on our inversion is minimal and that the western anisotropic zone is indeed confined to the northern hemisphere.

7
Geodynamic implications
Relating our seismic observations to geodynamical processes in the inner core is challenging due to the multiple mechanisms proposed to explain the formation of anisotropy and the generation of hemispheres. It is now widely accepted that anisotropy is caused by the alignment of iron crystals, which occurs either during solidification or afterwards through texturing. However, the phase of iron which is stable at inner core conditions remains debated. At inner core temperatures and pressures iron takes the form of hcp (hexagonal close packed), bcc (body centred cubic), or fcc (face centred cubic) crystals. Each phase displays varying intrinsic anisotropy, although the magnitude of anisotropy observed seismically also depends on the degree of crystal alignment. In order to test if our seismic observations would be able to constrain the phase of iron, we calculated the anisotropy of a single crystal of each phase of iron at inner conditions using values obtained by ab initio simulations from Vočadlo (2007) and Martorell et al. (2015) and calculated the corresponding seismic travel times (see Fig. S7). The precise magnitude of anisotropy of these phases of iron at inner core temperatures and pressures remains an open question and while hcp iron seems the most likely candidate to account for observed inner core anisotropy, fcc iron is yet to be ruled out. Details on calculating the velocity characteristics of single crystals of iron can be found in Appendix B.5.
To facilitate the comparison between the single crystal anisotropy from the mineral physics and the anisotropy variations in our models, we used the mean a, b, and c parameters from our models for three different locations and plot the corresponding predicted fractional travel times (Fig. 9

We are, however, making this comparison to encourage further research into the possibility that seismic anisotropy within different regions in the inner core could be explained by different phases of iron.
Anisotropic phases of iron, by themselves, do not account for the observed pattern of inner core anisotropy. The crystals must be aligned in a lattice preferred orientation (LPO) or alternatively in a shape preferred orientation (SPO), as a texture of randomly oriented anisotropic crystals would appear isotropic overall. Given a particular phase of iron, the question arises how this LPO is generated, and which mechanism(s) result in a heterogeneous distribution of this LPO. LPOs are commonly caused by post-solidification deformation, for the inner core one possible deformation mechanism would involve induced stresses causing axis symmetric flow, resulting in iron crystals aligning with this flow. A number of mechanisms have been proposed to create such texturing, including topographic relaxation (also known as equatorial growth, Yoshida et al. (1996)), whereby preferential growth at the equator of the inner core causes flow toward the poles due to geostatic forces. An alternative mechanism involves Maxwell stress or Lorentz forces induced by the magnetic field, causing deformation strongly influenced by outer core flow (Karato 1999; Buffett and Wenk 2001). It is likely that a combination of these mechanisms is required to explain the observed seismic complexity. For example, models of topographic relaxation typically produce symmetric flow around the equator which would create seismic anisotropy at both poles. This is in contrast to our observation that anisotropy in the inner core does not extend from south pole to north pole. Given this new observation, it is important that future geodynamical models assess whether topographic relaxation mechanisms can produce asymmetric flow around the equator, resulting in stronger anisotropy at the north pole than the south pole.
Hemispherical structures in the inner core are equally complicated to account for, and must further be compatible with the processes to generate anisotropy. Proposed hemispherical models are separated broadly based on whether the density or thermal profile in the inner core is stable. If the inner core has an unstable density or thermal profile, then convection becomes probable (Lythgoe and Deuss, 2015). For specific conditions (large viscosity and low thermal conductivity), this convection will be in the form of inner core translation which can result in a hemispherical pattern (Alboussiere et al. 2010; Deguen et al. 2018). An anisotropic fabric will be able to form if this translation is combined with a texturing mechanism such as topographical relaxation (Yoshida et al. 1996; Deguen et al. 2011), deformation due to magnetic forces (Karato, 1999) or annealing during translation (Bergman et al., 2010). For example, recent work by Frost et al. (2021) has shown that translation in the inner core is able to produce a region in the west with strong anisotropy. However, translation models require a high inner core viscosity (

Alternatively, variations in crystallisation rate at the inner core boundary could result in hemispherical differences being ‘frozen in’ as the inner core grows (Aubert et al., 2008). In this case, heat flux at the ICB would be influenced by flow in the outer core, the magnetic field, and potentially thermal anomalies at the core mantle boundary (Karato 1993). This mechanism of hemisphere formation implies that structures at increasing depth within the inner core record older properties of ICB properties, outer core flow, and magnetic field strength. This opens the potential to use seismology to infer paleomagnetic properties, but it is also unclear if anomalies in the outer core could last long enough to maintain a consistent pattern of crystallisation in the inner core, and whether this pattern could truly be preserved for substantial periods of time.


8
Conclusion
Our transdimensional-MCMC model of inner core seismic velocity shows that hemispherical structures and regional-scale variations in anisotropy are required to explain inner core body wave data. The observed features remain when removing anomalous data from earthquakes originating in the South Sandwich Islands, and also when using data corrected for 3D mantle structure. Our results reveal for the first time that the strong anisotropic region in the west is primarily located in the northern hemisphere, with implications for geodynamical models of inner core formation. This result is guided only by the data itself without any prior structure imposed in the parameterisation, and is robust even when considering uncertainties in the data and model space. We propose to call this an anisotropic zone (rather than hemisphere) to better describe its shape. We also find robust evidence for a innermost inner core, in which the slowest velocity is at an angle of

Its distinct anisotropy could indicate a different phase of iron (either bcc or fcc) than the rest of the inner core (hcp), and potentially result from multiple stages of inner core growth, while its offset is compatible with models of slow lateral translation.

Introduction
The prevalence of dykes gives rise to their application in many geological fields. Dyke swarms resulting from extensional tectonics have been observed to produce crustal widening on the scale of hundreds of meters to several kilometers across the world: the Troodos ophiolite, Cyprus (Moores and Vine, 1971; Varga, 1991), the Siberian platform (Polyansky et al., 2017) and NW Australia (Magee and Jackson, 2020) are well studied examples. Through ridge push, these have also been hypothesised as a contributer to the movement of tectonic plates (Swedan, 2015; Hou, 2012). On smaller scales, dykes supply volcanic eruptions and control lava output from vents and their closing and opening is vital in predicting subsequent lava flow (Kervyn et al., 2009). Investigations of shape evolution have been carried out and compared to field measurements in Rum, Scotland and Helam mine, South Africa (Daniels et al., 2012). These found that observed dyke shapes are narrower at the centre and wider at the tips than those predicted from elastic models. Further study into modelling dyke shape change is therefore important in developing a better understanding of the governing processes behind magma cooling from initial intrusion.
The cooling time-frames of emplaced magma varies between orders of months and kiloyears (Pansino et al., 2019), depending predominantly upon size and initial temperature in relation to the country rock (Jaeger, 1968). There are two main regimes by which this cooling occurs, as discussed previously by Bruce and Huppert (1989). The first is meltback, in which the initially formed chilled margins and the surrounding country rock can be melted prior to full crystallisation of the magma. The second is blocking, where the body crystallises upon emplacement and blocks the flow of magma. The extent of these regimes significantly alters the shape change of the dyke during cooling as well as the rate of cooling, and in turn crystal growth at various positions within the dyke (Platten and Watterson, 1969; Henriquez and Martin, 1978). This variation in crystal growth is commonly seen in the presence of chilled margins (Huppert and Sparks, 1989; Healy et al., 2018). Although these regimes have been qualitatively discussed in the above literature, quantitative analysis of the regime prevalence has undergone limited investigation.
Cooling of the body is predominantly controlled by conductive movement of heat within the magma (Delaney, 1986). Within dykes, convective heat transfers are relatively small in contrast to processes in large magma chambers (Worster et al., 1990). Consideration of temperature variations due to conduction in magma has been studied in numerous cases to provide analytic solutions (Carslaw and Jaeger, 1959) and in more general cases to yield numerical solutions (Alexiades and Solomon, 1993; Dehghan and Najafi, 2016). Advection can then be studied by considering the effects of magma reinjection or flow, as by Bruce and Huppert (1989).
This paper uses a numerical model to investigate temperature variation in a vertically emplaced dyke from an initial intrusion shape. Subsequent shape change and variation in cooling regimes are then evaluated. This is studied in the case of a single intrusion cooling without disturbance and in the case of further magma input through the remaining mobile melt. Numerical modelling of dyke cooling has been repeatedly undertaken (Delaney, 1986; Daniels et al., 2014; Petcovic and Dufek, 2005). These investigate cooling timeframes, dyke size and temperature variation in the surrounding country rock (the final case comparing these predictions to those observed in the Columbia River flood basalts). However, there is little literature investigating the dyke shape change (aspect ratio) during cooling in particular.

Validity of numerical model
This system of equations is known as a two-phase Stefan problem, with a range of melting/crystallisation temperatures. The boundary conditions are enforced by setting the temperature at each end of the x-domain after every timestep. A two dimensional solution can then be found by separately calculating the time evolution following discretised line-sections along the y-axis.

5.4
Errors and possible improvements
The main area for improvement upon this model would be to consider continuous flow, vertically through the dyke. This would occur only through the mobile melt portion of the dyke and so the information found on how the MME shape changes can be applied. The reinjection model used is also a discontinuous form of this flow and so gives rise to similar results as those found in section

4
. Times taken for total crystallisation found with the model used are of the order of months and years (reaching the order of 10 yrs for a dyke of half-width 10 m and reinjection periods near 0.115 yrs) as opposed to the maximum kiloyears estimated in Pansino et al. (2019), likely due to this lack of flow.
Density variation of the magma with temperature is another possible area of improvement. The density of magma increases as it cools; this is of the order of 
10

−
3

Another assumption that could have led to errors is that of the constant thermal properties of the magma and surrounding rock. As considered in section

2.1
, the effects of this consideration are shown to be most prevalent in the country rock immediately surrounding the magma, particularly in the case of larger igneous bodies (Nabelek et al., 2012). In this study primarily concerning the cooling of magma (as opposed to the temperature profile in the surrounding rock), the associated errors are deemed to have little effect on dyke shape and temperature within the melt. This is seen in the supplementary material, where the dyke shape-change is seen to take the same form as in the case with lower thermal conductivity. These models run at a lower thermal conductivity are also good indicators of the behaviour of magma surrounded by a country rock with increased porosity and at a higher temperature.
The assumption of the dyke's small aspect ratio is suitable here because the dyke dimensions are consistently such that the length is much greater than the width. However, in order to apply this model to larger, non-planar igneous bodies (batholiths and magma chambers for example), two and three dimensional heat diffusion models would need to be considered. In addition, convection is not investigated here [due to its second order effects in dykes (Delaney, 1986)] but is integral in the cooling mechanisms of larger bodies (Worster et al., 1990).


5.5
Comparison to geological examples
The narrowing of dykes during cooling discussed in section

5.1
 suggests that dykes have thinner centres and wider tips than expected based upon initial intrusion shape. This is seen in the field where dykes are often seen to have wider tips than expected. This has been observed in the Isle of Rum, Scotland and Helam mine, South Africa by Daniels et al. (2012) and in the Jagged Rocks Complex, USA by Re et al. (2015). This is commonly attributed to interaction between dyke tips and changes in composition of the country rock. The narrowing modelled here is purely the result of the magma cooling process and so suggests that both components are important in developing this dyke shape. This also indicates that modelling dyke tip interactions and varying country rock material would be appropriate areas to build upon this study.
Rapid cooling around the dyke perimeter is shown to occur in section

5.1
, giving rise to limited crystal development. This is particularly evident in the cases of narrow dykes with limited flow (
Fig. 4

d). These chilled margins are commonly seen in the field, giving rise to significantly different igneous textures at dyke margins compared to their centres (Healy et al., 2018).
The meltback regimes observed in Figs.

2

b and 
4

f suggest alteration of the country rock surrounding dykes upon emplacement. This is especially prevalent in the cases with magma reinjection. Similar partial melting of the rock and alteration via contact metamorphism is seen around large dykes in the Greenland and Canada (Denyszyn et al., 2004).
Repetitive magma reinjection along the same dykes is a common method of recharge for certain volcanoes - a well studied example of which is the Krafla fissure zone in Iceland (Marquart and Jacoby, 1985). The reinjection model used here can then be applied to the evolution of dyke shapes for these such volcanoes.



6
Conclusion
The current investigation shows that during the cooling of magma from initial emplacement, the horizontal cross-section shape of a dyke varies from its initial form by narrowing. In all blocking regimes, the solidus isotherm narrows continuously up until crystallisation, whereas the mobile melt extent (MME) isotherm first narrows before widening, prior to the melt becoming immobile. Meltback regimes show the form of both the solidus and MME to widen (aspect ratio increasing linearly with time) but with the MME being more responsive to subsequent magma reinjection and leading the solidus shape change in time.
In addition to this, the regimes of blocking and meltback are seen to be heavily reliant on the rate of magma input. In the static magma case, meltback is very rare, occurring only in cases where the country rock is at very high temperatures (within 300°C of the solidus) and gives rise to minimal partial melting of surrounding rock. With reinjection of magma, meltback can occur at far lower temperatures of country rock and give rise to significant partial melting. The period of reinjection and minimum dyke width for meltback are shown to follow a near linear relationship for periods of reinjection greater than 0.03 yrs.
Superheated intrusions are briefly considered and shown to increase the incidence of meltback when compared to magma emplaced at the liquidus temperature. As well as this, the greater the extent of superheating, the greater the increased widening of the MME isotherm shape during cooling, while having little to no effect on the evolution of the form of the solidus isotherm.
