Introduction
A combination of primordial and radiogenic energy drives Earth's engine, with the former coming from planetary accretion and the latter from decay of K, Th, and U. Our planetary vehicle lacks a fuel gauge to define the amount of fuel left to power plate tectonics, mantle convection, and the geodynamo. Defining the thermal evolution of the planet gives insights into the cooling and crystallization history of the core, the temporal variation in mantle viscosity, and the nature of the cosmic building blocks of the Earth. With the dawn of geoneutrino detection (Araki et al., 2005), we now have the opportunity to define the Earth's radiogenic fuel budget, which in turn can specify the proportional contribution of these heat producing elements (K, Th, U) in the crust and mantle.
Twenty years have passed since particle physicists began detecting the Earth's emission of geoneutrinos (chargeless and near-massless particles emitted during 


β


−


 decay) (Araki et al., 2005). The first generation of detectors (KamLAND in Japan and Borexino in Italy) have reported their flux measurements and interpreted their data in the context of an assumed geological model. The precision of the flux measurement (σ) continues to improve with exposure time, as it follow counting statistics (
σ
∼
1
/


N


, N=number of observed events). The accuracy of the interpretation and its uncertainties depends on the assumed geological model. To interpret the geoneutrino flux measurement, one uses a detailed assessment of the Th and U abundances and distribution in the lithosphere surrounding the detector (closest ∼500 km, which typically contributes 40 to 50% of the measured signal). A reference model is assumed for contributions from the remaining global lithosphere and mantle, with the Earth's core having negligible quantities of K, Th, and U, and no significant contribution to the signal. Combined analyses of the results from the KamLAND and Borexino experiments favor an Earth with ∼20 TW present-day total radiogenic power (or a ∼16 TW Earth for just Th and U power) (McDonough et al., 2020; Bellini et al., 2021). This finding indicates that ∼40% of the Earth's estimated power of 46 ± 3 TW (Jaupart et al., 2015) comes from radiogenic sources.
Controversy remains, however, regarding the assumed geological model used to describe the local lithospheric contribution to the geoneutrino flux. For the lithosphere surrounding the KamLAND detector the various geological models predicting the local 3D distribution of Th and U differ by a factor of 1.4, based on their reported geoneutrino fluxes (Enomoto, 2006; Huang et al., 2013; Wipperfurth et al., 2020). In contrast, for the Borexino detector the various predictions differ by a factor of 3 (Coltorti et al., 2011; Huang et al., 2013; Agostini et al., 2020; Wipperfurth et al., 2020). The interpretation of the regional geology is important for geoneutrino studies as it fundamentally influences the final result, and the global abundances of Th and U.
The latest interpretation of geoneutrino data from the Borexino experiment (Agostini et al., 2020) predicts a low contribution from their local crust to the overall geoneutrino signal. Consequently, their inferred mantle geoneutrino signal is high (∼25 TW from Th+U), as well as their calculation for the bulk Earth's radiogenic power (∼38 TW from K+Th+U), with model uncertainties at ∼34% (Agostini et al., 2020). This prediction contrasts with other geoneutrino experiments (Gando et al., 2013; Agostini et al., 2015) and numerous geochemical (McDonough and Sun, 1995; Javoy et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2013, e.g.) and geophysical (Turcotte and Schubert, 2014; Jaupart et al., 2016, e.g.) models for Earth. Agostini et al. (2020) places their upper limit of uncertainty at 51 TW of radiogenic heat production, which is outside of all geological observations.
Here we review the data for constructing a local geological model for the lithosphere immediately surrounding the Borexino detector. We evaluate the local geological model used in Agostini et al. (2020) and compare it with competing models. We then test whether such models are consistent with the known regional geology and heat flux constraints. Using these findings, we identify the best local lithospheric models for the Borexino experiment. Relying on the same principles, we discuss the competing local lithospheric models for the next generation of geoneutrino experiments.

The Apennines of the central Italian peninsula expose a geological paradox across its eastern and western divide. Its Adriatic eastern side is composed of a compressional fold and thrust belt, whereas its Tyrrhenian western side is composed of extensional fault-block mountains. 6
The future of neutrino geoscience
High resolution crustal models accounting for the specific types and proportions of lithologies surrounding each geoneutrino detector must be constructed to interpret geoneutrino flux measurement. The geology underlying active geoneutrino detectors (Fig. 8
) in Gran Sasso, Italy, Kamioka, Japan, and Sudbury, Canada, reveal complicated tectonic features (e.g., (paleo-)subduction and synorogenic extension, ocean-continent subduction zone, large impact structure). Geoneutrino data already exists from two of these locations, but these crustal models are either low resolution or in conflict with one another. We must reconcile the geoneutrino signal at each location with improved local and regional geology. We must use a wide range of independent geoscientific data to constrain the composition of the NFL. Moreover, our compositional models needs to be internally consistent with available heat flow, geochemistry/petrology, structural geology, and seismology data to reduce the systematic uncertainties on Earth's HPE content and thermal budget.
There are three more geoneutrino projects under construction or development: Jiangmen Underground Neutrino Observatory (JUNO, Fig. 8 purple dot) in southeastern China, which will be 20x larger than any existing detector (An et al., 2016); China Jinping Underground Laboratory (CJPL, Fig. 8 green dot) sited on the eastern slope of the Tibetan plateau and Himalayan ramp and at 2.4 km depth (Beacom et al., 2017); and OBD, a movable, Ocean Bottom Detector (Fig. 8 teal dot) proposed by a team of scientists and engineers working with JAMSTEC (Sakai et al., 2022). These projects each represent massive feats of engineering and decades-long data collection experiments and require substantial geoscientific input.
The decay of HPEs contributes substantially to Earth's internal heat. By quantifying Earth's geoneutrino flux, we can precisely establish how much fuel from HPEs is left to power mantle convection and the recycling processes of plate tectonics. Geoneutrinos studies use modern physics technology to measure directly and instantaneously the current compositional properties of the inaccessible mantle. Th and U exist in Earth in constant, chondritic ratios to 26 other elements (McDonough and Sun, 1995); if we constrain the abundance of HPEs, we can establish Earth's concentrations of Ca, Al, Nb, and the economically valuable rare earth elements. With the second generation of geoneutrino detectors on the horizon, geoscientists and physicists are poised to unravel Earth's heat budget from the tallest mountains to the bottom of the oceans.


7
Conclusion
The power of geoneutrino studies lies in directly quantifying the amount of heat producing elements in the bulk Earth. Deep reservoirs in Earth that before were unreachable are being sampled by particle physicists, but these studies have not reached a consensus on what their results mean for mantle heat production. The geoneutrino signal at a given detector is a combination of crust-sourced and mantle-sourced Th and U decays. Since geoneutrinos do not carry directional information, the lithospheric signal must be constrained to quantify the mantle's abundances of Th and U.
Approximately 50% of the geoneutrino signal is produced from the Near-Field Lithosphere (NFL), with 25% of the signal coming from the HPEs within 50 km of the detector. Conflicting Near-Field Lithospheric compositional models lead to profoundly different consequences for the predicted HPE content in the mantle and Earth's thermal evolution.
The Borexino particle physics team (Agostini et al., 2020) modeled the NFL surrounding their detector as predominantly carbonate, with low concentrations of Th and U. Their model therefore requires most of the geoneutrino signal to come from the distant mantle, implying a 30 TW of mantle radiogenic heat production. Consequently, >80% of all of the Earth's internal heat is radiogenic. This high heat production mantle is inconsistent with measurements from the detector at KamLAND and with heat flux observations.
Alternatively, the inclusion of Neogene to Recent, HPE-rich volcanic deposits in the Borexino NFL region results in a more normal average upper crustal composition for Th and U. Using this upper crustal model (versus a low HPE model) can explain the Borexino signal, resulting in 13 TW of radiogenic power in the mantle or a 20 TW radiogenic Earth. It is therefore imperative to produce high-resolution NFL maps with accurate proportions of each HPE lithology.
The direct measurement of geoneutrinos can provide crucial insights into the sources and distribution of heat producing elements in the Earth. When paired with accurate geological knowledge, these high-energy antineutrinos emitted from HPE decays within Earth help establish the composition of the planet's building blocks as well as the fuel left to power Earth's dynamic interior.

1
Introduction
Volatile elements are crucial in planetary evolution as they regulate atmosphere formation, mantle dynamics through mantle melting and regassing, and thus climate evolution and planetary habitability (e.g., Kaltenegger, 2017; van Keken et al., 2011). Understanding the evolution of volatile elements on terrestrial planets is therefore required to investigate habitability in exoplanetary systems (Kaltenegger, 2017).
The noble gas compositions of Earth's mantle sources record the sources of volatiles as well as evolutionary processes such as recycling through subduction and degassing (e.g., Marty, 2012; Moreira, 2013; Mukhopadhyay and Parai, 2019). However, mantle-derived samples, such as basaltic glass, often show a pervasive atmospheric contamination (Ballentine and Barfod, 2000; Mukhopadhyay and Parai, 2019), which prevents precisely determining the mantle noble gas composition. As such, little is known about the deep mantle heavy noble gases krypton and xenon, which are particularly powerful tracers in elucidating accretion and loss of volatiles to the Earth, along with Earth's early degassing history (Broadley et al., 2020a; Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Parai et al., 2019; Péron et al., 2021).
The Earth's atmosphere shows a xenon depletion relative to chondrites, with the Xe/Kr ratio being about one order of magnitude lower than chondrites (Bekaert et al., 2020; Dauphas, 2003; Halliday, 2013; Marty, 2012; Pepin, 1991; Pepin and Porcelli, 2002). This missing Xe was initially assigned to Xe loss from the atmosphere via hydrodynamic escape early in Earth's history (Pepin, 1991; Pepin and Porcelli, 2002). But, atmospheric Xe was later observed to have been lost progressively from the Archean to 2.4 Ga ago (Almayrac et al., 2021; Ardoin et al., 2022; Avice et al., 2018; Pujol et al., 2011). Some studies have overcome the issue of shallow atmospheric contamination of mantle-derived samples and show a Xe depletion relative to chondrites in the mantle as well (e.g., Moreira et al., 1998; Mukhopadhyay and Parai, 2019; Trieloff and Kunz, 2005). However, about 90% of the deep mantle Xe was shown to be recycled atmospheric Xe (Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Parai and Mukhopadhyay, 2015; Pető et al., 2013), although the fractions of mantle Ar and Kr from recycling are not precisely known. Therefore, it is unclear whether the mantle xenon depletion was present in the early Earth, what its magnitude might have been, or whether the signature was acquired through recycling of the Xe depleted atmosphere.
To overcome the atmospheric contamination issue, we used a recently developed gas accumulation protocol to precisely measure krypton and xenon isotopes in basaltic glass samples from the Galápagos and Iceland hotspots (Péron et al., 2021). The Galápagos and Iceland hotspots show among the most primitive 3He/4He and 20Ne/22Ne ratios on Earth along with negative tungsten anomalies that reflects mantle heterogeneities created in the first 60 Myr of solar system formation (Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Mundl-Petermeier et al., 2020; Péron et al., 2016). Hence, both hotspots are ideal locations to investigate volatile evolution in the early Earth.
Here, we present a new approach to determine the initial noble gas elemental ratios of mantle sources. Atmospheric heavy noble gases (Ar, Kr, Xe) are recycled into the mantle at subduction zones through sediments and altered oceanic crust (Chavrit et al., 2016; Holland and Ballentine, 2006; Kendrick et al., 2013; Matsumoto et al., 2001; Parai and Mukhopadhyay, 2015). Consequently, the present-day elemental noble gas compositions are a mixture of initial and recycled atmospheric noble gases. In this study, using the precise Kr and Xe isotopic measurements from Galápagos and Iceland (Péron et al., 2021), we corrected the measured (present-day) elemental ratios for recycling to obtain the pre-subduction deep mantle elemental noble gas composition. Crucially, this new approach shows that the deep mantle was initially depleted in Xe relative to chondrites and the magnitude of the depletion was larger than in the modern-day atmosphere. Possible scenarios to account for this depletion are discussed.


2
Methods
The samples and noble gas analyses are described in details in Péron et al. (2021). For the purpose of this article, they are briefly summarized below.

2.1
Samples
To determine the deep mantle noble gas elemental pattern, we used basaltic glass samples from Fernandina, Galápagos and from Midfell, Iceland. These two hotspots present high 3He/4He ratios (>15 Ra, with Ra the atmospheric 3He/4He isotopic ratio) and the most primitive neon isotopic ratios, with 20Ne/22Ne > 12.8 for both hotspots (Kurz et al., 2009; Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Péron et al., 2021; Trieloff et al., 2000). Hence, their noble gas compositions are supposed to reflect that of a nearly undegassed, more primordial deep mantle reservoir (Kurz et al., 2009; Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Trieloff et al., 2000).
Samples AHA-NEMO2-D22A and AHA-NEMO2-D22B (hereafter D22A and D22B respectively, and D22 to include all samples) were collected from a submarine lava flow of Fernandina volcano (Geist et al., 2006; Kurz et al., 2009). Both samples show 4He/40Ar* ratios (40Ar* being radiogenic 40Ar) between 3.6-4.0 (Table 1
), in agreement with literature data (Péron et al., 2016), and within the range of the mantle production ratio 2-5 (Moreira and Kurz, 2013).
The Midfell sample (hereafter DG2017) was collected at the same location as the DICE sample from a subglacial lava flow (Péron et al., 2021) and shows a noble gas (He, Ne, Ar, Xe) isotopic compositions very similar to DICE (Colin et al., 2015; Harrison et al., 1999; Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Trieloff et al., 2000). Sample DG-2017 has a 4He/40Ar* ratio of 2.80 ± 0.02, in agreement with previous measurements for the DICE sample, which have a 4He/40Ar* ratio between 1.2 and 3.0 (Colin et al., 2015; Harrison et al., 1999; Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Trieloff et al., 2000), so within the range of the mantle production ratio.
Since He is about ten times more soluble in basaltic melts than Ar (Jambon et al., 1986), He and Ar can be fractionated during magmatic degassing (e.g., open system degassing). The 4He/40Ar* is thus a proxy of degassing. If the measured 4He/40Ar* ratios are close to the mantle production ratio (Moreira and Kurz, 2013), then no or minimal elemental fractionation has occurred and the measured elemental ratios are representative of the mantle source composition. Similarly, the 4He/21Ne* and 40Ar*/21Ne* ratios (21Ne* being nucleogenic 21Ne) of the samples are close to the mantle production ratios, indicating either no, or negligible, elemental fractionation (Table 1). Therefore, the measured noble gas elemental patterns of the Galápagos and Iceland samples are representative of these two deep mantle sources.


2.2
Noble gas analyses
The He, Ne and Ar compositions of the Galápagos and Iceland hotspots have been well studied (e.g., Colin et al., 2015; Furi et al., 2010; Harrison et al., 1999; Kurz et al., 2009; Moreira et al., 2001; Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Péron et al., 2016; Trieloff et al., 2000). Due to the low abundances of Kr and Xe in these samples and the ubiquitous atmospheric contamination, the compositions of krypton and non-radiogenic xenon isotopes have only been determined recently (Péron et al., 2021). The new methodology used allows for the recovery of high purity fractions of Kr and Xe, nearly free of atmospheric contaminants (Péron et al., 2021). Sample D22A was measured once, sample D22B three times (D22B-1, D22B-2, D22B-3) and sample DG2017 twice (DG2017-1, DG2017-2). The isotopic ratios are discussed in Péron et al. (2021), while this study focuses on the elemental ratios, in particular on the Xe/Kr ratios.
From the noble gas measurements (Péron et al., 2021), the present-day noble gas elemental patterns of the Galápagos and Iceland hotspots are determined here. The measured Xe/Kr ratios are representative of the mantle sources as the new methodology used removes nearly all the surficial atmospheric Kr and Xe contamination. However, the methodology did not remove most of the surficial atmospheric Ar contamination (Péron et al., 2021), and so the measured 36Ar/84Kr ratios need to be corrected. To do so, the 36Ar/84Kr ratios can be extrapolated to a mantle source 40Ar/36Ar ratio of ∼ 8,500 (Supplementary Information) as the Galápagos and Iceland hotspots have 40Ar/36Ar ratios of ∼ 8,500 (Colin et al., 2015; Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Péron et al., 2016; Trieloff et al., 2000). Similarly, the Ne/Kr ratios can be corrected for the small Ne atmospheric contaminant by extrapolating the measured (average) 20Ne/22Ne ratios (Supplementary Information) to a mantle source 20Ne/22Ne ratio of 12.90 (Colin et al., 2015; Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Péron et al., 2016; Trieloff et al., 2000).


2.3
Determination of the pre-subduction noble gas elemental ratios
The measured noble gas elemental patterns, corrected for shallow atmospheric contamination, as described above and in Supplementary Information, are the present-day elemental compositions of the mantle sources, which are an integration of the initial and recycled atmospheric signatures.
In this study, we estimate the initial noble gas elemental patterns of the Galápagos and Iceland mantle sources by correcting the present-day average elemental ratios for atmospheric recycling (Table 1) as follows: Rcorr = (Fini
i/Fini
j)*Rmeasured, with R= Abi/Abj the ratio of abundances of elements i and j and Fini the initial proportion (=1-Frecycled) of each element. Hence, to apply the correction, the recycled atmospheric proportions (Frecycled) need to be evaluated for each noble gas. Note that this approach is different than the study of Yamamoto and Kurz (2022) which estimated the present-day elemental ratios, not the elemental ratios before subduction of atmospheric gases.
The proportions of recycled atmospheric Kr in the Galápagos and Iceland mantle sources have been determined in a previous study based on the 78Kr/84Kr and 80Kr/84Kr ratios (Péron et al., 2021) considering either Phase Q or Average Carbonaceous Chondrites (AVCC) as the initial source. Importantly, while the 86Kr/84Kr ratio is usually the most precise Kr isotopic ratio, the 86Kr/84Kr ratio cannot be used to determine the proportion of recycled atmospheric Kr, since the deep mantle, at least as sampled by the Galápagos and Iceland mantle sources, has a deficit in 86Kr relative to AVCC (Péron et al., 2021). Precise 78Kr/84Kr and 80Kr/84Kr ratios have only been measured for the Galápagos and Iceland hotspots. Therefore, for other mantle-derived samples for which precise Kr isotopic measurements exist (Broadley et al., 2020a; Holland et al., 2009), we use the 82Kr/84Kr ratio to estimate the proportion of recycled atmospheric Kr as a precaution, even if a deficit in 86Kr has not yet been ascertained for these mantle sources. The isotopes 82Kr and 84Kr are non-radiogenic in the mantle (the fission production of 84Kr is negligible in the mantle (Ozima and Podosek, 2002)) and so the mantle 82Kr/84Kr ratio is a mixture of initial Kr and recycled atmospheric Kr. For Yellowstone, such an estimate is only possible for sample 4B as sample 4A shows a 82Kr/84Kr ratio lower than AVCC (Broadley et al., 2020a). For CO2 well gases, representing the Mid-Ocean Ridge Basalt (MORB) mantle, we take the lowest measured 82Kr/84Kr corrected for crustal fission (0.2015 ± 0.0001) (Holland et al., 2009). For both Yellowstone and CO2 well gases, Phase Q does not seem an appropriate starting composition as they have 82Kr/84Kr ratios intermediate between AVCC and Phase Q.
To estimate the proportions of recycled atmospheric xenon, we consider the 128Xe/130Xe ratios. Since 128Xe and 130Xe are both non-radiogenic isotopes, the present-day mantle 128Xe/130Xe ratio reflects a mixing between initial Xe and recycled atmospheric xenon. For the starting Xe isotopic composition, we use AVCC or Phase Q. The measured 128Xe/130Xe of Yellowstone is first normalized to an atmospheric 128Xe/130Xe ratio of 0.471 as in Péron et al. (2021) since a value of 0.4715 was used in the original study (Broadley et al., 2020a). For both the proportions of recycled Kr (29-64%) and Xe (90-96%) in the mantle sources, errors have been propagated taking into account uncertainties on measured isotopic ratios for the mantle sources and initial chondritic compositions (AVCC, Phase Q).
As neon is likely not recycled efficiently in the mantle (Tucker and Mukhopadhyay, 2014), we do not correct the neon abundance for recycling, that is we consider that 100% of present-day neon is from the initial source. A small amount of recycled neon in the mantle would not change the results of this study. Indeed, if initially the deep mantle had a 20Ne/22Ne ratio of about 13.4 (Williams and Mukhopadhyay, 2019), then lowering this ratio to the maximum measured values of about 12.9-13.0 (Péron et al., 2021; Williams and Mukhopadhyay, 2019) owing to subducted atmospheric Ne would indicate only 10-15% of the Ne is recycled in origin (Kendrick et al., 2018).
The case for Ar is less straightforward. Some studies argued that most (64%-100%) of the non-radiogenic Ar (36Ar and 38Ar) in the mantle is of recycled origin (Holland and Ballentine, 2006; Tucker et al., 2022). This is supported by the fact that the 38Ar/36Ar ratio is atmospheric within uncertainties in the deep and MORB mantle (Raquin and Moreira, 2009). If about 100% of the budget of non-radiogenic Ar is from recycling, then the initial mantle 36Ar/84Kr ratio would be close to 0 (Table 1), which does not seem very likely. The precision on the measured 38Ar/36Ar ratio does not currently allow to distinguish whether the 38Ar/36Ar ratio is atmospheric, chondritic or intermediate between the two, as Phase Q has a 38Ar/36Ar ratio of 0.1873 ± 0.0007 (Busemann et al., 2000), very close to the atmospheric ratio (0.1880). Instead, we note a progression in the percentage of recycled atmospheric gases from Xe, to Kr to Ne with ≥90%, to around 50%, to <15%, respectively. Therefore, we hypothesize that for Ar, the recycled proportion may range between that of Ne and Kr – i.e., 30 ± 20% of Ar is from recycling, which covers the range of recycling from Ne to Kr. We further note that the Xe/Kr ratio is the primary focus of the study and uncertainties in the proportion of recycled Ar in the mantle will not affect any of our main conclusions.

4
Discussion
Noble gas primordial isotopic ratios (e.g., 20Ne/22Ne) and radiogenic/non-radiogenic isotopic ratios (e.g., 129Xe/130Xe) represent tracers of volatile sources as well as processes such as degassing and regassing. Noble gas elemental ratios are likewise affected by source compositions and physical processes such as magma ocean outgassing and core formation. Therefore, elemental ratios provide additional constraints on processes that have affected Earth's volatile accretion and evolution. Here, we first establish a Xe deficit in the deep mantle in section 4.1, then discuss the noble gas recycling efficiencies in section 4.2, and finally propose possible processes responsible for the deep mantle Xe depletion in section 4.3.

4.1
Identification of a Xe deficit in the deep mantle
The main observation from this study is that the deep mantle 130Xe/84Kr ratios corrected for atmospheric recycling are significantly lower than the atmospheric and seawater values. In other words, the initial deep mantle 130Xe/84Kr ratio was lower than any known sources (Fig. 4), and hence there was a significant deficit of xenon relative to krypton in the Earth's deep mantle. Xenon was depleted relative to chondrites by two orders of magnitude (Tables 1, 2 and Fig. 4). Xenon also appears depleted in the MORB mantle, although to a much lesser extent. More measurements would be needed to confirm such an observation for MORB mantle sources. We now explore whether mantle degassing associated with partial melting, recycling of surficial atmospheric gases, or some combination of the two can produce the extremely low Xe/Kr ratio in the mantle if the starting interior composition was near chondritic.
Partial melting and degassing in its present-day style could potentially fractionate xenon from krypton, but only if both elements had significantly different crystal/melt partition coefficients. Given the incompatibility of Kr and Xe (see Supplementary Information for arguments about potential compatible behavior of Xe) during partial melting (Brooker et al., 2003; Heber et al., 2007), loss of volatiles from the mantle through plate-tectonic style degassing processes would not change the mantle's Xe/Kr ratio. The krypton and xenon olivine-melt and clinopyroxene-melt partition coefficients are relatively similar, on the order of 10−4 (Heber et al., 2007). Using Heber et al. (2007)'s partitioning data, and assuming a typical partial melting of 1-10%, the Xe/Kr ratio could vary by at most <10%. Similarly, the processes of recycling and mixing slabs in the mantle, assuming no surficial gases in the slabs for the time being, would not change the Xe/Kr ratio by two orders of magnitude. Taking the same approach as Tucker and Mukhopadhyay (2014) with the largest differences in the Kr and Xe partition coefficients (Heber et al., 2007), an average partial melting of 5%, and a mantle composition with 60% olivine, 20% clinopyroxene, 20% orthopyroxene (assuming the Kr and Xe partition coefficients are similar for clinopyroxene and orthopyroxene), we determine that the Xe/Kr ratio of the mantle could vary by at most 18% after 10 reservoir masses have been processed. Therefore, partial melting and recycling of barren slabs into the mantle cannot explain why the initial mantle Xe/Kr ratio is depleted by two orders of magnitude compared to chondritic values.
We consider whether injection of surficial gases into the mantle could be responsible for the observed Xe/Kr ratio. The atmosphere Xe/Kr ratio is about one order of magnitude lower than chondrites (Dauphas, 2003; Halliday, 2013; Marty, 2012; Pepin, 1991; Pepin and Porcelli, 2002). Atmospheric xenon is also enriched in heavy isotopes relative to solar and chondritic xenon by about 3-4% amu−1 (Avice et al., 2018; Marty, 2012; Pepin, 1991). These two characteristics are known as the missing xenon paradox. A theoretical starting composition, called U-Xe, combined with xenon loss from the atmosphere, can explain the xenon isotopic feature of Earth's atmosphere (Pepin, 1991; Pepin and Porcelli, 2002). The U-Xe composition has since been found to consist of a mixture of about 20% cometary Xe with 80% chondritic Xe (Marty et al., 2017). Analyses of ancient atmospheric xenon trapped in fluid inclusions of Archean cherts and barites show that the atmospheric xenon isotopic composition progressively evolved from the U-Xe composition to reach the present-day composition at around 2.4 Ga (Ardoin et al., 2022; Avice et al., 2018; Pujol et al., 2011). Contrary to models that suggest Xe loss from the Earth's atmosphere associated with accretional processes (e.g., Pepin, 1991), the Archean chert observations require protracted Xe loss from Earth's atmosphere over the first 2.4 Ga (e.g., Ardoin et al., 2022). Subduction of gases from post-2.4 Ga surficial reservoirs (atmosphere, seawater), however, cannot explain the Xe deficit (low Xe/Kr) of the deep interior as the interior has a lower Xe/Kr than the surface. Pre-2.4 Ga, the surface reservoirs would have a lower degree of xenon depletion and a higher Xe/Kr than the modern-day atmosphere (Broadley et al., 2022). Thus, subduction early in Earth's history, if prevalent, would pose an even bigger challenge in explaining the low Xe/Kr of the deep interior. Hence, recycling of ancient or modern atmosphere is not a viable process to account for the deep mantle Xe depletion. Furthermore, given the very small variations in Xe/Kr ratios induced by mantle outgassing and partial melting, recycling of surficial gases combined with mantle outgassing and partial melting cannot explain the exceedingly low Xe/Kr ratio in the Earth's deep interior (Fig. 4).
The evidence from the 3He/22Ne ratio, I/Pu-derived Xe and 


μ


182


W show that the deep mantle was largely isolated from the rest of the mantle by about 4.45 Ga ago (Mukhopadhyay, 2012; Mundl-Petermeier et al., 2020; Tucker and Mukhopadhyay, 2014). As the deep mantle Xe depletion cannot be acquired from subduction of surficial gases reservoirs at any time during Earth's history, the xenon depletion in the deep mantle occurred very early, most likely during Earth's accretion. Later on, the deep mantle was partly replenished in Xe from recycling of atmospheric heavy noble gases via subduction (Parai and Mukhopadhyay, 2015) although atmospheric Xe was not recycled efficiently into the mantle before 3 Ga ago (Parai and Mukhopadhyay, 2018; Péron and Moreira, 2018). In contrast to the mantle Xe deficit being set at accretion, the xenon deficit in the atmosphere was acquired over a protracted time through Xe loss to space involving trapping of ionized xenon onto organics or hydrodynamic escape of ionized xenon (Avice et al., 2018; Hébrard and Marty, 2014; Pepin, 1991; Zahnle et al., 2019). Thus, the magnitude, timing and process(es) of xenon depletion are different between the Earth's interior and the atmosphere and ‘missing xenon’ in the Earth's interior and atmosphere are two separate and distinct problems.


4.2
Noble gas recycling efficiencies into the mantle

4.2.1
The case for Ar
As mentioned in Section 2.3, the proportion of recycled atmospheric Ar in the mantle remains unclear although the general assumption has been that about 100% of mantle's non-radiogenic Ar budget is from recycled origin (Holland and Ballentine, 2006). However, the recycling efficiency of Ar may be expected to be more similar to Kr (or lower). Such a hypothesis is supported by enrichments in Kr and Xe over Ar in most of the altered recycled oceanic crust and serpentinites compared to seawater (Chavrit et al., 2016; Kendrick et al., 2013), and experimentally determined Ar solubilities in serpentinites that are lower compared to Kr and Xe (Krantz et al., 2019). Furthermore, we suggest that during subduction, Ar might be preferentially lost over Kr and Xe through diffusion at depths corresponding to arc magma genesis and preferentially returned to the surface via arc volcanism. The hypothesis of Ar not being significantly recycled into the mantle is in agreement with a recent study showing that ingassing 36Ar fluxes are balanced by outgassing 36Ar fluxes in the Central American subduction zone (Labidi et al., 2021). We, therefore, hypothesize that a substantial fraction of non-radiogenic mantle Ar is of primordial origin, between ∼50 and ∼86% to reflect the recycling range between Ne and Kr (in other words, between ∼14 and ∼50% of non-radiogenic Ar would be from recycling). Such a proportion for primordial Ar in the mantle would still result in 38Ar/36Ar ratios very close to the atmospheric value (> 0.187) if Phase Q or AVCC was the starting composition (Busemann et al., 2000; Mazor et al., 1970; Pepin, 1991). On the contrary, if initial mantle Ar was more similar to solar (Heber et al., 2009), the present-day mantle would be expected to have 38Ar/36Ar ratios < 0.187 with such a high proportion of initial Ar. Unequivocal evidence for such low values has not yet been presented. High precision measurements on 38Ar/36Ar ratios for samples minimally affected by air contamination are needed to better evaluate the proportion of recycled atmospheric Ar in the mantle.


4.2.2
The case for Kr and Xe
After correcting for recycling, the initial 130Xe/84Kr ratios of the Galápagos and Iceland mantle sources are lower than the atmospheric and seawater values, whereas their present-day ratios are similar to seawater within uncertainties (Tables 1 and 2). Therefore, the recycling component may have a 130Xe/84Kr ratio similar to, or higher than seawater. The curvature of the hyperbolic mixing in a 128Xe/130Xe vs. 78Kr/84Kr space (Fig. 5
) is r = (130Xe/84Kr)initial mantle/(130Xe/84Kr)recycled component, with the initial mantle having AVCC-like Kr and Xe isotopic ratios and the recycled component having an atmospheric Kr and Xe isotopic composition. Considering the average isotopic ratios for Galápagos and Iceland, we determined with the Matlab function fit that the hyperbola curvature r is 0.092 ± 0.019 (1 σ) in Fig. 5. Given the corrected 130Xe/84Kr ratio of the Galápagos and Iceland mantle sources (Table 2) and the curvature of the hyperbola, we calculate that the recycled component would have a 130Xe/84Kr ratio of ∼ 0.013 - 0.014, that is slightly higher than seawater. Uncertainties on this latter value are large (∼ 0.01) as it depends on the uncertainties of the initial mantle (corrected) 130Xe/84Kr ratio, which in turn depends on the uncertainties of the measured Kr and Xe isotopic ratios at Galápagos and Iceland (Péron et al., 2021). More measurements of the Kr and Xe isotopic composition of the deep mantle would allow one to refine these estimates. Nonetheless, the recycled component appears to be similar to, or slightly enriched in Xe relative to seawater. Therefore, assuming that the Xe/Kr ratio of the subducting package is similar to that of seawater, Xe would be as efficiently recycled, or slightly more efficiently recycled into the mantle compared to Kr.
The significant xenon depletion in the deep mantle compared to krypton, along with the recycling efficiency of Xe being at least as high as Kr suggests that the initial isotopic composition of xenon would be more susceptible to being overprinted by recycling of atmospheric noble gases. This provides an explanation for why only barely resolvable excesses in the non-radiogenic 124Xe/130Xe, 126Xe/130Xe and 128Xe/130Xe ratios relative to air are detected in deep mantle sources, and why the proportions of initial Xe in the deep mantle are much lower compared to Kr (Péron et al., 2021). In contrast, the MORB mantle shows higher excesses relative to air for the non-radiogenic Xe isotopes (Holland and Ballentine, 2006; Péron and Moreira, 2018), which may be due to a lower extent of Xe depletion and so higher proportions of initial Xe compared to the deep mantle (Parai and Mukhopadhyay, 2015).



4.3
Origin of the deep mantle Xe deficit
Several processes, discussed below, are envisaged to generate a xenon deficit in mantle sources. Partial melting and degassing, along with subduction of surficial noble gases, discussed in section 4.1, are shown not to cause significant Xe/Kr variations. But, three other processes could possibly account for the deep mantle xenon deficit, namely partitioning of Xe into the core, magma ocean outgassing and a low Xe/Kr ratio of the Earth's parent bodies, none of which are mutually exclusive.

4.3.1
Partitioning of Xe into the core
Evidence for partitioning of xenon into the Earth's core are limited and remain highly debated, as reviewed by Sanloup (2020). Xe metallization occurs at about 155 GPa (Eremets et al., 2000). Initial experimental determination of Xe behavior at pressures up to 150 GPa did not find evidence for alloy formation between Xe and Fe (Caldwell et al., 1997). While ab-initio calculations showed that Xe could form an alloy with hexagonally closed-packed iron at pressures relevant for the Earth's core (Lee and Steinle-Neumann, 2006), experimental evidence suggested that Xe does not form an alloy with iron at conditions relevant for the Earth's outer core (Nishio-Hamane et al., 2010). Recent, first-principles calculations with structure search, and experiments, suggest that Xe could form stable compounds with Fe and Ni (XeFe3 and XeNi3) above 200 GPa, relevant for inner core conditions (Stavrou et al., 2018; Zhu et al., 2014).
Although Xe could be incorporated into the Earth's core through formation of Xe-Ni and Xe-Fe compounds, how much Xe could be removed into the core through these reactions remains unclear. In particular, the Earth's core is thought to have formed at much lower pressures (around 50 GPa in average), which would not have allowed Xe alloy formation during core formation (Stavrou et al., 2018). However, we cannot rule out that xenon was sequestered into the core at a later stage, after magma ocean solidification, through deep mantle – core equilibration. Such a scenario would run counter to ideas of the core fluxing the deep mantle with primordial noble gases. Importantly, to explain the deep mantle xenon deficit, Xe would need to be preferentially incorporated into the core over Kr. Whether Kr would form an alloy with Fe and Ni is not known (Sanloup, 2020).
Another possibility for preferentially removing Xe over Kr into the core during Earth's accretion is through metal and silicate equilibration in a magma ocean. At lower pressures of 6 GPa, Xe has a slight preference over Kr for a metallic liquid, although for both gases the metal-silicate partition coefficient is < 1 (Matsuda et al., 1993). However, the relative solubilities of krypton and xenon in metal and silicate liquids at high pressures and high temperatures relevant to core formation have not been determined. Only the Kr storage capacity of ferropericlase and liquid iron has been experimentally determined up to 60-115 GPa and suggest a limited Kr content in metallic liquid compared to ferropericlase (Rosa et al., 2020). Thus, we cannot completely assess whether metal-silicate equilibration may have preferentially partitioned Xe over Kr into the core and led to the deep Earth's Xe depletion.


4.3.2
Magma ocean outgassing
During a magma ocean stage, the Xe/Kr ratio of the magma ocean in equilibrium with an atmosphere can be changed by a factor equal to the solubility ratio of the two gases. Although the krypton and xenon solubilities for the temperatures and compositions relevant to magma ocean have not been determined, xenon is the noble gas with the lowest solubility in silicate melts (Carroll and Stolper, 1993; Jambon et al., 1986). The Xe/Kr solubility ratio (SXe/SKr) was determined to be about 0.43-0.57 for basaltic melt at 1350-1400 °C (Jambon et al., 1986; Lux, 1987). Hence, one mechanism to decrease the deep mantle Xe/Kr ratio compared to the chondritic ratio could be magma ocean outgassing.
If deep mantle krypton and xenon originated from chondrites, or more broadly from meteorites, as isotopic data suggest (Broadley et al., 2020a; Péron et al., 2021), then the deep mantle Xe/Kr ratio could be decreased from

While this calculation is based on solubilities in a basaltic liquid, a magma ocean would be ultramafic with a liquidus temperature of 2000 K. The Xe/Kr solubility ratio for an ultramafic liquid would have to be more than a factor of 100 different from that in a basaltic liquid to explain the observed deep Earth Xe/Kr through a single stage of magma ocean outgassing. If magma ocean outgassing was responsible for the deep mantle Xe deficit, then several magma ocean outgassing stages would be needed. Note that ingassing into a magma ocean from a chondritic-like Kr, Xe atmosphere would also generate a lower Xe/Kr ratio in the magma ocean compared to the chondritic values according to the solubility ratio. Ingassing followed by several magma ocean outgassing stages may account for the deep mantle Xe deficit. However, several magma ocean outgassing phases, or ingassing combined with several magma ocean outgassing phases would also increase the 3He/22Ne ratio of the deep Earth above values of 2.5-3, which is not consistent with the observations (Tucker and Mukhopadhyay, 2014). Therefore, magma ocean outgassing (and ingassing) does not seem like a viable process on its own to explain the deep mantle Xe deficit relative to chondrites. The MORB mantle may, however, have experienced more than one phase of magma ocean outgassing (Tucker and Mukhopadhyay, 2014), potentially accounting for part of the Xe depletion in the MORB mantle relative to chondrites.


4.3.3
Low Xe/Kr ratio of the Earth's parent bodies
A third possibility to account for the initially low Xe/Kr ratio of the deep mantle may be Earth's building blocks were carrying such a signature. Building blocks with nearly two orders of magnitude Xe deficits relative to chondritic Kr abundances, but with Kr and Xe isotopic ratios similar to chondrites, would be required. No potential volatile sources have been identified so far with such a chemical signature (Fig. 4). We note that for some other isotope systems, such as Nd, Mo, Ru, the Earth is an end-member and no mixtures of known meteorites would produce the Earth's isotopic composition (e.g., Render et al., 2017).
Earth may have accreted from differentiated bodies as represented by achondrites (Carlson et al., 2014). Some ureilites, achondrites from the inner solar system, show lower Xe/Kr ratios, up to a factor 5 lower than Phase Q (Broadley et al., 2020b). However, achondrites, including ureilites, show Kr isotopic compositions similar to Phase Q (Broadley et al., 2020b) and initial deep mantle Kr does not match Phase Q isotopically (Péron et al., 2021). Thus, whether achondrites could account for the deep mantle noble gas budget remains unclear.
Comets may have a xenon deficit relative to Kr and chondrites. Experiments of gas trapping in ices carried out to investigate the potential cometary compositions show that, starting from a solar composition, ices end up with a low Xe/Kr ratio, at least a factor of two lower compared to the solar ratio (Bar-Nun and Owen, 1998; Owen et al., 1992).
Measurements of the coma of the comet 67P/C-G during the Rosetta mission found a 130Xe/84Kr ratio of about 0.042 (Marty et al., 2017; Rubin et al., 2018), which is lower than chondritic values but considerably higher than the observed values for the deep Earth (Fig. 4). Hence, comets seem to show a Xe depletion relative to Kr and chondrites, but the possible extent of this depletion by itself does not seem to be able to match the observed value in the deep Earth. The lack of observational data from comets do not allow us to conclude whether comet 67P/C-G is representative of other cometary objects. Nonetheless, given the experimental data and observation from comet 67P/C-G, the deep mantle Xe depletion may be partly attributed to the Earth's parent bodies.
From an isotopic perspective, comets have Kr isotopic ratios more similar to solar with potentially a deficit in 86Kr, based on data from comet 67P/C-G (Rubin et al., 2018). The deep mantle shows Kr isotopic ratios close to chondritic values with a deficit in 86Kr interpreted as a nucleosynthetic anomaly (Péron et al., 2021). The deep mantle Kr and Xe elemental and isotopic data would then require a mix of chondritic objects with cometary-like bodies carrying a low Xe/Kr ratio and a deficit in 86Kr. We note that the origin of the nucleosynthetic 86Kr anomaly in the deep mantle remains unclear and may be carried by other meteorites not yet in our collections (Péron et al., 2021). Overall, our study highlights that different types of planetesimals, some possibly from the outer solar system, may have contributed to the deep mantle volatile budget.


4.3.4
Summary
The three scenarios discussed above, partitioning of Xe into the core, magma ocean outgassing and a low Xe/Kr ratio of the Earth's parent bodies, by themselves, seem unable to explain the unusually low Xe/Kr ratio of the Earth's deep mantle. Potentially, all of these processes, acting in sync, may have contributed towards producing the deep mantle Xe deficit relative to chondrites. A more critical evaluation of these hypotheses, along with the relative importance of these processes, will require xenon partitioning data between metal and silicates at high pressures and temperatures as well as krypton and xenon solubilities in ultramafic liquids at the conditions of a magma ocean. Additional measurements of extraterrestrial material will also be crucial towards this goal.




5
Conclusions
We determined the noble gas elemental pattern of mantle sources prior to the introduction of recycled atmospheric noble gases into the mantle, i.e., the mantle's initial elemental pattern. The initial deep mantle source patterns show a xenon depletion of about two orders of magnitude relative to chondritic values, and a larger xenon depletion relative to krypton compared to the modern-day atmosphere. This xenon depletion relative to krypton was most likely acquired during Earth's formation as degassing associated with partial melting processes and subduction of surficial noble gases cannot produce the mantle's observed Xe/Kr ratio. The MORB mantle also seems to have a Xe depletion that is larger than the atmosphere, but to a lesser extent than the deep mantle. More data are needed for the MORB mantle sources to confirm this observation.
Three processes are envisaged to explain the initial Xe deficit of the deep mantle: (i) core-mantle interactions, (ii) magma ocean outgassing, (iii) low Xe/Kr ratio of the parent bodies. These processes, acting individually, may not explain the deep mantle xenon deficit. However, the three scenarios are not mutually exclusive and a combination of volatile source(s) with core-mantle partitioning and magma ocean outgassing may have been responsible for the initial deep mantle composition.

Introduction
It is generally agreed that a mantle convective upwelling centered beneath Iceland plays a role in generating and maintaining anomalous vertical elevations across the North Atlantic region (Fig. 1
a). Throughout this region, present-day oceanic spreading ridges and plates are 1–2 km shallower than expected and fringing continental margins are elevated (White and McKenzie, 1989). Existence of a large mantle plume with a buoyancy flux of up to 20 Mgs−1 has been confirmed by regional seismic tomographic models which image a substantial and irregular-shaped negative shear-wave velocity anomaly beneath the lithospheric plates (e.g. Schoonman et al., 2017). There is interest in determining how the Icelandic plume has evolved through geologic time (White and McKenzie, 1989). The spatial and temporal distribution of Cenozoic magmatism suggests that this plume initiated at about 64 Myrs and that its planform rapidly expanded. At 55 Myrs, continental rifting and seafloor spreading accompanied large-scale basaltic magmatism triggered by decompression melting. Plume activity has also waxed and waned on shorter timescales. Compelling evidence for fluctuating plume behavior relies on the fact that the plume is transected by a mid-oceanic ridge, which acts as a linear window into temporal variability of the underlying thermal structure. The resultant pattern of time-transgressive V-shaped ridges and troughs that straddle the Reykjanes Ridge south of Iceland enables a record of radial thermal fluctuations to be reconstructed (Parnell-Turner et al., 2014). Our primary aim is to determine the extent to which there may be a genetic relationship between plume activity and transient landscape development and whether or not these events intrude upon the global climatic signal. Finally, we suggest that the combination of Icelandic plume activity and lithospheric rifting between Greenland and Northwest Europe triggered a longer period oscillation of Paleogene cooling and warming. This oscillation can be accounted for by regional silicate weathering during the initial stages of plume activity followed by a period of volcanic degassing when plume-generated magmatism increased during separation of the North American and Eurasian plates.


2
Stratigraphic unconformities and ancient buried landscapes

2.1
Regional framework
We describe a sequence of buried terrestrial landscapes that punctuate Cenozoic marine strata within the Faroe-Shetland basin (Fig. 1b). These landscapes were mapped on a 3D seismic reflection survey that covers 
2
×


10


4


 km2 (Appendix). This survey is calibrated with 36 boreholes, enabling lithologic, biostratigraphic and depositional constraints to be integrated with reflectivity mapping. The chronology of significant stratigraphic events is determined using a detailed regional biostratigraphic framework that has been recalibrated with respect to a modern orbitally tuned global timescale (Fig. 2
; Speijer et al., 2020; Mudge and Bujak, 2001). This framework is based upon bioevents of dinoflagellate cysts, foraminifera, pollen, radiolaria and diatoms from four boreholes located along the axis of the Faroe-Shetland basin (Fig. 1c; Supplementary Information). Biostratigraphic analysis is primarily based upon conventional core and sidewall core material, supplemented by ditch cuttings.
The sedimentary basin was formed by Late Cretaceous lithospheric rifting followed by Cenozoic thermal subsidence (Shaw Champion et al., 2008). Paleogene stratigraphy is characterized by marine deposition that is interrupted by erosional unconformities, which are capped by terrestrial strata (Knox et al., 1997). We examine in detail four surfaces, Q–T, that were sub-aerially exposed, incised and rapidly buried. There is regional evidence for a fifth older surface which is not mappable within the Faroe-Shetland basin. On a single vertical slice through the seismic volume, these four stacked surfaces are manifest as irregular reflective surfaces (Fig. 3
). Each surface was mapped by hand-picking in-lines and cross-lines (i.e. orthogonal vertical slices) with a resolution of ∼30 m. Post-depositional folding is removed from unconformities Q and R by flattening the top surface of the Balder Formation and from unconformities S and T by flattening topset surfaces of the Stronsay delta. Depth conversion, decompaction and isostatic unloading were carried out using 29 borehole checkshot surveys (Appendix; Shaw Champion et al., 2008). These four landscapes reveal patterns of dendritic drainage characterized by over-steepened slopes and spurs that are typical of eroding landscapes where soft lithologies undergo rapid uplift (Fig. 4
).


2.2
Landscape Q
The oldest Landscape Q initiated at 59.15 ± 0.45 Myrs when an erosional unconformity cut into the underlying Vaila Formation. This formation comprises marine carbonate muds and sandstones (Figs. 2 and 3b; Knox et al., 1997). The pattern of erosional incision together with subsequent deposition of lignite are consistent with development of a fluvial landscape. The age of this important sequence boundary, which marks the top of the Vaila Formation, is biostratigraphically constrained by a marked change of the dominant dinocyst species from Areoligera cf. coronata and P. pyrophorum to Areoligera gippingensis (Mudge and Bujak, 2001). Immediately above this boundary, the agglutinated foraminifera Reticulophragmium cf. garcilassoi, which is confined to Thanetian times, occurs. The exposure duration of Landscape Q is limited to ≤2.5 Myr since the short-lived Alisocysta margarita occurs immediately above and below the sequence boundary (Speijer et al., 2020). This buried landscape is dominated by a major catchment with a prominent sinuous channel that has a relief of 310 m (Fig. 4a). Interlocking spurs occur within the higher reaches of this channel where steep tributaries are visible. Landscape Q is overlain by the Kettla Tuff Member of the Lamba Formation (Fig. 3; Knox et al., 1997). This tuff manifests a surge of volcanism associated with Phase 1 of the North Atlantic Igneous Province (White and McKenzie, 1989).


2.3
Landscape R
The overlying Lamba Formation comprises a prograding deltaic sequence that contains Thanetian agglutinated benthic foraminifera, notably S. spectabilis and Reticulophragmium cf. garcilassoi, confirming the transient nature of Landscape Q (Knox et al., 1997). The upper boundary of this formation is the exquisitely preserved Landscape R, which initiated at 55.80 ± 0.8 Myrs (Shaw Champion et al., 2008; Hartley et al., 2011). From a biostratigraphic perspective, this sequence boundary marks a dramatic shift from agglutinated benthic foraminifera to calcareous benthic foraminifera and diatom-restricted microfaunas (Mudge and Bujak, 2001). The short-lived Apectodinium augustum, which is characteristically abundant at this boundary, defines the Thanetian-Ypresian transition at 56 Myrs (Fig. 2). Sub-aerial exposure of Landscape R lasted <2 Myrs in accordance with the first and last appearance datums of Apectodinium augustum within the Flett formation, the common occurrence of Cerodinium wardenense, and the abundant occurrence of Caryapollenites spp. (Fig. 2; Mudge and Bujak, 2001; Speijer et al., 2020).
We revised and augmented the mapping of this landscape using additional seismic reflection surveys (Fig. 4b). It is bisected by a dramatic meandering channel, which has ∼8 major tributary channels. The spatial pattern of knickzones along these channels delineates three peneplains at elevations of 200 m, 450 m and 750 m with reference to the base of the prominent paleo-seacliff (Supplementary Information). Landscape R has a relief of 500–750 m. It is infilled by the Flett Formation, which is a terrestrial unit containing lignite beds and pollen assemblages dominated by Bombacacidites and Caryapollenites (Fig. 3; Mudge and Bujak, 2001). This formation is overlain by tuffs and mudstones of the Balder Formation, heralding a rapid return to marine conditions (Fig. 3; Knox et al., 1997). An equivalent landscape is recognized in the North Sea basin (Stucky de Quay et al., 2017).


2.4
Landscapes S and T
The lower part of the overlying Stronsay Group comprises ∼100 m-high northward prograding clinoformal surfaces dominated by marine sandstones and mudstones (Fig. 3). Upper surfaces of two deltas have rugose geometries that constitute landscapes S and T (Fig. 4c and d). Both landscapes are overlain by lignite fragments, by carbonaceous material, and by tuffs, indicative of sub-aerial exposure with coeval volcanism. A combination of the first appearance datum of Dracodinium simile within underlying strata and last appearance datums of Homotryblium tenuispinosum and Dracodinium politum within overlying strata shows that this pair of landscapes developed between 54.3 and 51.7 Myrs (Speijer et al., 2020). In the adjacent Rockall basin, Stoker et al. (2012) document the existence of two sub-aerially exposed unconformities that correspond to landscapes S and T. The stratigraphic section that spans both unconformities correlates with nannoplankton zone NP10 and with lowermost NP12, based upon the combined presence of Adnatosphaeridium multispinosum, Adnatosphaeridium robustum, Achilleodinium biformoides, Achomosphaera alcicornu, Homotryblium tenuispinosum and Wetzeliella spp. Significantly landscapes S and T and their temporal equivalents in the Rockall basin are separated by occurrences of Deflandrea oebisfeldensis, which has a last appearance datum of ∼53 Myrs. Thus, it is safe to conclude that Landscape S was incised between 54.3 and 53.0 Myrs and that Landscape T was incised between 53.0 and 51.7 Myrs. Landscape S is characterized by a large canyon with steep slopes above which lies an extensive peneplain (Fig. 4c). This canyon is 25 km long and cuts down into prograding clinoformal surfaces of the underlying deltaic deposits (Fig. 3). Minor catchments occur along the eastern escarpment. Landscape T is characterized by a series of catchments that are distributed along a 15 km-long northeast-facing slope (Fig. 4d).


2.5
Regional context
We contend that the degree of exquisite detail recorded by these preserved landscapes and recovered by 3D seismic reflection surveying is remarkable. The causes of this unprecedented degree of preservation are threefold. First, these landscapes developed within a paleoenvironmental Goldilocks zone which enhanced their preservation potential. If pre-existing water depths had been greater than several hundred meters, it is unlikely that this continental margin would have been sub-aerially exposed at all. If, on the other hand, pre-existing water depths had been negligible, more prolonged sub-aerial exposure would have given rise to wholesale peneplanation. Secondly, regional uplift was short-lived, which means that these transient landscapes were rapidly submerged. Thirdly, subsequent sedimentation rates were rapid so that submarine erosion did not occur (Supplementary Information). This particular combination of water depth, transient uplift and sedimentation rate has ensured preservation of these delicately sculpted surfaces.
Fragmentary evidence supports the existence of these four buried landscapes throughout the North Atlantic region (Fig. 1a). However, erosional surfaces are often featureless peneplains where only the deepest incised structures are locally preserved. For example, in the Paris basin a 6–7 Myr hiatus between Thanetian sedimentary rocks of the Chalons sur Vesles and Moulin Compensé formations and underlying Danian chalk deposits has been linked to a regional uplift event that coincides with Landscape Q (Gale and Lovell, 2020). In southern England, a similar hiatus occurs between the Thanet Formation and Late Cretaceous deposits where ∼500 m of chalk are absent. However, both hiatuses are too protracted to make definitive correlations. In the Kangerlussuaq basin of East Greenland, the Vandfaldsdalen Formation, consisting of pillow basalts and hyaloclastites, is overlain by lava flows with oxidized surfaces, implying a transition from submarine to sub-aerial conditions that is coeval with Landscape Q (Brooks, 2011). Burgeoning evidence supports the regional extent of Landscape R. For example, a deeply incised erosional surface lies beneath the Harwich formation of the London basin (King, 2016). Here, the estuarine Blackheath Formation records a return to marine conditions by ∼55 Myrs. This major sequence boundary is one of a number of erosional surfaces that occur throughout southern England at this time. Coeval erosional surfaces are recognized along the Norwegian and Greenland continental margins and on the fringes of the Jan Mayen microcontinent (see, e.g., Ren et al., 2003; Storey et al., 2007; Dalhoff et al., 2003). There is widespread evidence supporting the existence of landscapes S and T. In the Kortrijk region of Belgium, the boundary between the Upper and Lower Roubaix Clay Formation is a marked erosional surface that represents relative sea-level fall (Steurbaut and King, 2017). This boundary is correlated with the deeply incised base of the Portsmouth Member of the Hampshire basin and it is coeval with Landscape T. Coastal outcrops along Van Keulenfjorden of Spitsbergen preserve slope deposits of the Batfjellet Formation onto which landscapes are sculpted and then overlain by the Aspelintoppen Formation (Plink-Björklund and Steel, 2006). The stratigraphic setting, morphology and estimated duration suggest that these landscapes are coeval with S and T. Sudermann et al. (2021) describe a stratigraphic succession at Stenkul Fiord of Ellesmere Island where a volcanic ash band with a U/Pb age of 
53.7
±

Finally, there is fragmentary field evidence for an erosional surface that precedes Landscape Q. For example, Dam (2002) describes an unconformity associated with sub-aerial exposure in the Nuussuaq region of West Greenland (Landscape P). Terrestrial sandstones of the Paatuutkløften Formation cut down into marine mudstones of the mid-Danian Tupaasat Formation by ∼200 m. Fan deposition is absent at distal boreholes of the Faroe-Shetland basin, where sedimentation is dominated by mudstones, which exhibit discrete spikes of gamma ray intensity that are coeval with individual landscapes (Appendix). If sedimentary composition is relatively uniform, these spikes may be indicative of a relative increase in terrestrially sourced material enriched by radioactive elements or of an organic bloom generated by enhanced erosion and delivery of nutrients. Another well-known mechanism that can trigger such spikes is an increase in carbonate dissolution triggered by a reduction in the carbonate saturation state through the rapid addition of CO2.

Osmium isotopic records, mercury concentrations and radiometrically dated volcanic rocks from the continental fringes of the North Atlantic Ocean reveal an excellent temporal coherence between the North Atlantic Igneous Province (NAIP) and the PETM event (Storey et al., 2007; Dickson et al., 2015; Jones et al., 2019a). This coherence suggests that basaltic magmatism, generated by fluctuations of the Icelandic plume, is a trigger for significant addition of 13C-depleted carbon to surficial reservoirs during the PETM event. However, the composition and origin of carbon species is much debated. We note that the volume of magmatism associated with the NAIP is sufficient to account for the volume of carbon but that positive feedback effects can also amplify climatic change (Gutjahr et al., 2017; Jones et al., 2019b). Analysis of an inventory of hydrothermal vents along the Norwegian continental margin suggests that methane generated by contact metamorphism could have been a primary source of carbon (Svensen et al., 2004; Frieling et al., 2016). Regional uplift and disruption to oceanic circulation could also be associated with methane release triggered by dissociation of gas hydrate deposits (Bice and Marotzke, 2002).
Reconciling the short (i.e. ∼200 ka) duration of the PETM event with the duration of NAIP volcanism is regarded as challenging (Storey et al., 2007). It is straightforward to estimate the transit time of a thermal fluctuation that horizontally advects beneath a lithospheric plate by considering what happens when a V-shaped ridge forms at a mid-oceanic ridge. Conclusions
There is considerable interest in developing a quantitative understanding of rapid climatic changes within the geologic record. In recent decades, this understanding has been predicated upon the astronomical framework of orbital cyclicity. However, there are notable aberrations and exceptional trends that cannot easily be accounted for by this framework. During Paleogene times, for example, global hyperthermal events that are superimposed upon a longer period climatic oscillation occur, neither of which have obvious explanations. These events are of particular importance because they are regarded as ancient analogues of present-day climate change. One of the best known is the PETM event, which represents

Mantle convective processes and volcanism are often proposed as significant potential contributors to Earth surface processes and to climate change. However, there is a general perception that these mechanisms occur on timescales that are too slow to account for events on time scales of O(100) kyr. The observations that we present here should help to overturn this perception. Throughout the North Atlantic region, there is evidence for repeated transient vertical displacements of the Earth's surface that cannot be accounted for by glacio-eustatic mechanisms. These displacements are indirectly recorded as buried ephemeral landscapes. The best-preserved landscapes share common attributes with hyperthermal events— they occur at the same times, they are geologically rapid, and they coincide with excursions of gamma ray intensity. We infer that thermal fluctuations of the Icelandic mantle plume played a role in triggering some of these hyperthermal events. Several of these events are characterized by double-spiked excursions which may be hallmarks either of eccentric forcing or of staged uplift events for which there is independent geologic evidence (Hartley et al., 2011).
Our results have far-reaching implications. The Milankovitch hypothesis has, for excellent reasons, provided a superb quantitative framework for interpreting stratigraphic and isotopic records. However, it is becoming clear that tectonic events driven by mantle convective dynamics can intrude upon this rhythmic tempo. The best-known hyperthermal events appear to fall within a long-period climatic oscillation which may itself have been triggered by the two-stage evolution of the Icelandic plume which could have enhanced sensitivity to orbital forcing. The events themselves coincide with, and can be at least partly explained by, episodes of transient landscape development that are linked with short-period fluctuations in plume activity. In conclusion, we suggest that a detailed and integrated multi-disciplinary analysis of the Icelandic plume across a range of spatial and temporal scales should bear fruitful paleoclimatic insights.

Introduction
Olivine-hosted melt inclusions (OHMIs) often record large variations in major, volatile and trace elements that reflect different extents of melting, depths of entrapment or influences from slab fluids on the mantle source (e.g., Kent, 2008). Most data consist of major, trace and volatile elements. Studies reporting stable and radiogenic isotopes measured in melt inclusions are rare (e.g., Koornneef et al., 2019; Maclennan, 2008; Rose-Koga et al., 2012; Saal et al., 2002; Stracke et al., 2019), with only nine reporting oxygen isotopes (Bouvier et al., 2008, 2010, 2019; Gurenko et al., 2001; Gurenko and Chaussidon, 2002; Hartley et al., 2012, 2013; Manzini et al., 2019). 3.1
SIMS
Oxygen isotopes in olivines have been measured by secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) on a IMS 1280HR at the University of Lausanne, following the same protocol as Manzini et al. In brief, a 2nA primary Cs+ beam was focused on the sample, and secondary 16O and 18O ions were measured on faraday cups in multicollection mode, using a 2460 mass resolution (M/ΔM). A 30 sec pre-sputtering was set at the beginning of each analysis, and total acquisition time was almost 4 minutes per analysis. Four in-house olivine standards were used to calculate the instrumental mass fractionation as a function of Fo (Mg/(Fe+Mg) mole ratio) content (Supplementary Material 3). The laser diameter on the sample was 30 or 50 μm (for analysis of olivines) to 10 or 20 μm (for analysis of OHMIs) depending on the size of the MI or available area in the olivine. The O2 was then analysed with a Thermo Finningan MAT 253 mass spectrometer. Discussion

5.1
The magmatic history of the olivines
The olivines in this study do not have high enough Fo (>90) and NiO (>0.3 wt%), and low enough CaO (<0.1 wt%) to have originated in the mantle, suggesting a magmatic origin (Fig. 3b-c). The distribution of olivine compositions can be defined by three end-members: 1) Fo ∼90, high NiO (>0.3 wt%) and low CaO (∼0.12 wt%); 2) Fo ∼90, CaO >0.4 wt% but low NiO (0.10 wt%); and 3) low Fo, CaO ∼0.12 wt% and low NiO (0.04 wt%). Endmember (1) reflects olivine crystallised from a melt derived from mantle peridotite, whereas (3) represents olivine crystallised from an evolved melt derived from the mantle. The second primitive component (2), defined by olivines from Vulcano, represents olivine that has crystallised from ultra-calcic, alkali-rich melts. These melts are interpreted to result from the reaction between hot primitive melts and wehrlitic or gabbroic lithologies at 250 to 350 MPa (Lanzo et al., 2016). Olivines from Aoba seem to form two groups, resulting from mixing between end members (2) and (3). The contribution of both clinopyroxenite and peridotite to the melts beneath Aoba is also reported by Sorbadere et al. (2011).
The variation in Fo content in each olivine crystal provides valuable information on magmatic processes. Normal zoning (a rim with lower Fo) is likely to represent magmatic evolution or magma mixing with a more evolved melt, whereas reverse zoning strongly suggests that the olivine has grown in two different melt compositions, with the second one being more primitive than the melt in which the olivine started growing. These Fo variations can only be preserved if the olivine residence time at high temperature is short (e.g., several years, Costa et al., 2008). All five olivines from Vulcano have homogeneous Fo (intra-grain and grain-to-grain), which either suggests a long residence time that erases Fo zoning or formation of the olivine in a primitive melt with no magma mixing until eruption. Iwate and Sukumoyama olivines have different magmatic histories, reflected by the different types of zoning (reverse or normal). Aoba and St. Vincent olivines are either unzoned or have normal zoning (Table 1), suggesting that some of the olivine retain a record of magmatic evolution. Olivines from Aoba and St. Vincent also display complex zoning, suggesting at least three different magmatic steps.

Disequilibrium could be explained if an olivine trapped a different melt than the one in which it initially grew. This could happen during magma mixing and olivine remobilization. These scenarios are illustrated in Fig. 8
. Initially, an olivine crystallizes deep in the magmatic plumbing system, trapping melt inclusions (Fig. 8B). During ascent, the olivine enters the upper lens. Partial dissolution of the crystal edges will create reentrants in the olivine filled by a melt that is a mixture of the lower lens and upper lens melts, or only the upper lens melt if olivine has started to partially dissolve during ascent. This would lead, for example, to reverse zoning in some olivines if the crystals had been remobilized by a more mafic melt, as observed in olivines Izu_4, Izu_5, Iwate_2 and Iwate_5 from Sukumoyama and Iwate. 5.4
Implications
Episodic recharge of melt pockets or magma chambers is widely recognized as a possible trigger for volcanic eruptions (e.g., Sparks et al., 1977). The proportion of remobilized and partly recrystallized crystals could provide valuable information about the plumbing system of a volcano: a high proportion of remobilized olivine suggests a high proportion of crystals in the last melt pocket, or that the ascending melt has scavenged crystals from different melt pockets as it ascended.
Olivine partial dissolution due to temperature increase and/or decompression, followed by infilling with a melt not necessarily in elemental and isotopic equilibrium with the initial olivine, explains the different major and trace element compositions of OHMIs trapped in a single crystal (e.g., olivines SVN181 from St. Vincent, Ao3-1, Ao15-10 olivines from Aoba in this study, or, for example ARP73-10-03_16, CH77-DR6-203_45 and CH77-DR6-203_55 from Mid-Atlantic Ridge, in Manzini et al., 2019). Such episodes of remobilization or mixing might not always be evident based solely on the major element composition of the olivine, due to fast Fe-Mg diffusion (e.g., Jurewicz and Watson, 1988; Gaetani and Watson, 2002). Thus, local O isotopic equilibrium between the OHMI and the host crystal provides more robust information. Furthermore, if melt inclusions are forming during olivine recrystallization, OHMIs within the same olivine host may not necessarily be trapped at the same P-T conditions even though the olivine is homogeneous in composition.

Conclusions
Oxygen isotopes in olivines and OHMIs in basalts from five volcanoes located in different arcs exhibit a broad range of values that overlap, but with averages that differ from arc to arc. The variability measured in the olivines is not related to the variability measured in the OHMIs that they host. Olivines from four of the five volcanoes record either normal magmatic evolution or magma mixing, based on their Fo and 


δ


18


O compositions. A relatively large proportion of the measurements (70% of XX51 olivine-OHMI pairs) suggest that the OHMIs are not in O isotopic equilibrium with their host, despite their major element compositions being in apparent equilibrium. The O isotopic disequilibrium cannot be explained by temperature variations, as this is not resolvable by SIMS measurements. Trace elements in the OHMIs and their host olivines do not support O isotope disequilibrium being a boundary layer effect. Analysing the olivines in more detail reveals that for most of the olivines at least one O isotope measurement is in equilibrium with each of the OHMIs that it hosts. The olivine domains that are in equilibrium with the OHMI are often <50 μm from the inclusions. It is concluded that these OHMIs were trapped when the olivines were remobilized by melts with different 


δ
